A woman watches election results come in on a monitor at the Michigan Democratic election night party at the Motor City Casino in Detroit, Michigan. | Bill Pugliano/Getty Images Elections Midterm election: Here’s what’s happening now House called for Democrats, Republicans kept the Senate, and the first round of the 2021 redistricting battles arrives.

Voters across the country are heading to the polls for a midterm election that is expected to shatter recent turnout records in non-presidential years. Here are the five biggest stories of the election:

Democrats haven retaken the House majority, netting 27 seats so far.

Story Continued Below

Swept out of power in the 2010 tea party wave, Democrats are hoping to capitalize on backlash against President Donald Trump with gains big enough to recapture the chamber. POLITICO’s final race ratings have 216 seats leaning to Democrats — just under the 218 needed for a majority — and 197 seats in the Republican column, with 22 seats left as toss-ups. Democrats have to flip 23 districts in order to take the House, and with so many tight races, a small swing could mean the difference between a “blue wave” and Republicans narrowly holding onto their majority.

So far, Democrats have won 29 GOP-held seats, while Republicans have clawed two back. The pickups are mostly GOP-held districts that Hillary Clinton carried in 2016, like Virginia's 10th District, where Democrat Jennifer Wexton beat Rep. Barbara Comstock (R-Va.) for Democrats' first pickup of the night. But big Democratic surprises came out of Staten Island, where Max Rose beat Republican Rep. Dan Donovan in New York's 11th District, and in Oklahoma, where Democrat Kendra Horn notched a long-shot victory over GOP Rep. Steve Russell in a heavily Republican district. Democrat Joe Cunningham also defeated Republican Katie Arrington in South Carolina's 1st District, where Arrington defeated GOP Rep. Mark Sanford in a primary earlier this year.

(See POLITICO’s House results page here.)

COUNTDOWN TO 2020 The race for 2020 starts now. Stay in the know. Follow our presidential election coverage. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Republicans expand their Senate majority, beating three Democratic incumbents.

The Senate landscape looks very different than the House, with Democrats largely playing defense and three incumbents losing in red states: Indiana's Joe Donnelly lost to Republican Mike Braun; Missouri's Claire McCaskill lost to Republican Josh Hawley; and North Dakota's Heidi Heitkamp lost to Republican Kevin Cramer. Republicans also held on to Tennessee, where GOP Rep. Marsha Blackburn defeated former Democratic Gov. Phil Bredesen. Republicans still have targets to expand their Senate majority, currently at 51-49. In Florida, the battle between Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) and GOP Gov. Rick Scott is incredibly close. Scott currently leads Nelson with nearly all precincts reporting.

Democrats are looking for a few flips of their own, with their best chances against Sen. Dean Heller in Nevada and in an open seat in Arizona. But Republicans beat their candidates in Tennessee and Texas, two long-shot races.

In Mississippi, GOP Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith will face Democrat Mike Espy in a special election runoff.

(See POLITICO’s Senate results page here.)

Split decision in the statehouses

Republicans currently hold 33 governorships, but Democrats are hoping retake power in statehouses around the country. Democrats have won three open governor's races in GOP states so far: Illinois, where Democrat J.B. Pritzker defeated Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner; Michigan, where Democrat Gretchen Whitmer beat Republican Bill Schuette; and Kansas, where Democrat Laura Kelly beat Trump-aligned Republican Kris Kobach, but lost two other Great Plains races in Oklahoma and South Dakota. In Ohio, Democrats suffered a defeat where Republican Mike DeWine defeated Democrat Richard Cordray. They also lost a chance to take down Republican Gov. Kim Reynolds in Iowa. But in Wisconsin, Democrat Tony Evers has a very narrow lead over Republican Gov. Scott Walker.

Meanwhile, East Coast Republicans like Govs. Larry Hogan (Maryland) and Charlie Baker (Massachusetts) proved resilient in their states, winning comfortably despite Democratic attempts to tie them to Trump. GOP governors in New Hampshire and Vermont won reelection, and Republicans are currently leading in Connecticut, too.

These governors races are also a first step toward power over redistricting after the next census. Governors elected to four-year terms on Tuesday will be able to sign or veto congressional and state legislative maps in many states in 2021 and 2022.

poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201811/1126/1155968404_5857425402001_5857421155001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404" true

Gillum concedes in Florida

Democrats were left disappointed in Florida, after Andrew Gillum conceded the gubernatorial race to former GOP Rep. Ron DeSantis. Gillum was one of two Democrats hoping to make history by becoming the first black governor in their states. The other, Democrat Stacey Abrams, would be the first black female governor in U.S. history if she wins in Georgia. Abrams trails Republican Brian Kemp with most of the vote counted.

How Democrats won the House

For Democrats to flip the House , they needed to gain 23 seats. Any fewer and Republicans would maintain control.

Voters open their umbrellas as they step into the rain as they leave a polling station in New York. | Mark Lennihan/AP photo elections Several states extend voting hours as malfunctions, long lines mar polling places 'Were this to happen in my or any other East European country, the U.S. would label this a 'voting irregularity,'' a former Estonian president tweeted.

No signs of Russian meddling or malicious hackers popped up immediately in Tuesday's midterm elections, but eyewitnesses, watchdog groups and government officials reported a nationwide spate of mechanical problems, power outages, poor planning and seriously soggy weather that left many would-be voters waiting in exorbitantly long lines.

From sopping-wet paper to missing power plugs to ballot shortages, election supervisors were scrambling to keep the mostly technical glitches from depressing turnout in an election that both major parties see as a referendum on President Donald Trump. And several states extended their voting hours — or were forced to — so that people would have more time to cast ballots.

Story Continued Below

In Texas, a federal judge ordered officials to keep nine polling locations near Houston open an extra hour longer. That happened after Texas' Civil Rights Project sued officials in Harris County, where many voters gave up after waiting in line for hours due to technological issues, Vice reported. Polling stations were expected to remain open until 8 p.m. local time.

Illinois, Georgia, North Carolina, Indiana and Alabama also extended their voting hours, ABC reported.

COUNTDOWN TO 2020 The race for 2020 starts now. Stay in the know. Follow our presidential election coverage. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Voting in a precinct in Columbus County, N.C., was extended until 9:20 p.m. EST after voting was interrupted for two hours because one style of ballot was unavailable. Voting in Monroe County, Ind., was extended until 7 p.m. EST because of long lines, although people voting after 6 p.m. would have to do so through a provisional ballot. Four precincts in Chicago were expected to remain open an hour longer and another precinct would be open for an additional two hours because of the polling sites opening late.

A polling place at Annistown Elementary School in Gwinnett County, just northeast of Atlanta, opened 25 minutes late because the machines had technical issues, Candice Broce, spokeswoman for the Georgia Secretary of State’s Office, told CNN. Polls were expected to stay open at that school for an additional two hours and 25 minutes, until 9:25 p.m.

The NAACP announced via a tweet that additional precincts in Georgia had extended their voting times until as late as10 p.m. in response to a lawsuit filed by the civil rights group.

Some candidates took to urging their voters not to ditch the polling place.

"STAY IN LINE TO VOTE!" tweeted Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin, a front-runner in West Virginia's race despite competing in one of the most pro-Trump states in the union. "If you're in a long line at a polling place, you can stay in line and vote if you get in line before 7:30PM!"

Former Estonian President Toomas Hendrik Ilves called one of the reported problems — a shortage of ballots in one Texas precinct — a black eye for the reputation of U.S. democracy.

"No offence, dear followers, but were this to happen in my or any other East European country, the U.S. would label this a 'voting irregularity,'" he said on Twitter, ”... you know, one of those things that happens in far away places you can’t locate on a map."

Here are some of the issues that arose at polling places Tuesday:

Maryland

Voters in polling sites in Prince George's County, Md., faced a ballot shortage after unexpectedly high turnout and heavy traffic hindered election workers from delivering additional ballots to those locations, said Daneen Banks, deputy administration for the county Board of Elections, according to WTOP. Voters waited for as long as four hours.

Texas

A polling place in Arlington, Texas, failed to have enough paper ballots for an entire precinct, according to a CNN report, which said the Texas secretary of state's office was making emergency ballots available. The Texas Senate race between Democratic candidate Beto O' Rourke and Republican incumbent Ted Cruz is one of Tuesday's most high-profile and expensive races.

Georgia

Voters in Georgia were facing some of the biggest backups, with waits of more than three hours in some places. The watchdog group Common Cause chalked it up to high voter turnout blended with too few voting machines, ballots and workers, according to The Associated Press.

At a polling site at Atlanta’s Pittman Park Recreation Center, five additional voter machines were finally dispatched on top of the three originally dispatched there, according to CNN, which quoted Fulton County spokeswoman April Majors.

New York/ New Jersey

Tuesday's rain caused failures in scanners after they were fed wet ballots, officials in New York complained. City Council Speaker Corey Johnson tweeted that the moisture caused all but one scanner to fail in his polling place in Manhattan. Brooklyn Councilman Jumaane Williams tweeted about similar problems occurring in his district.

"This is a predictable problem we MUST fix and plan for next time!" Johnson tweeted, tagging the city's Board of Elections.

The New York attorney general's office reported receiving 350 calls and emails as of 3:30 p.m., of which roughly 100 were about malfunctioning and broken scanners, according to a tweet from communication director Amy Spitalnick. Another top complaint included sites, mainly outside of New York City, improperly requiring photo identification.

In Brooklyn’s Bereukelen Community Center, one voter complained that poll workers did not have keys for the doors when the location was supposed to open at 6 a.m., telling voters to return an hour later, television station WPIX reported. But finally, firefighters opened the doors to the location.

One of the members of the media cuts a hole in the ceiling of the press tent just before the start of Florida Democratic gubernatorial candidate Andrew Gillum's election night watch party at Florida A&M University. The media was evacuated out of the tent due to heavy rain and lightning. | Mark Wallheiser/Getty Images

Several New York voters also tweeted about similar malfunctions, causing long waits to vote. The city's Board of Elections has dispatched mechanics to fix the machines, New York City's Eyewitness News reported. The New York news station reported complaints from all five boroughs.

In downtown Jersey City, lines were reportedly up to two hours long. Gov. Phil Murphy’s communication director, Mahen Gunaratna, tweeted a video of the line at 8:05 a.m.

Tennessee

A polling place in Knoxville did not have power and the site’s backup generator had also failed, resulting in voters voting outside. Cliff Rodgers, administrator for elections for Knox County, told CNN that he ordered more paper ballots to Cedar Bluff Middle School.

Pennsylvania

The individual responsible for opening a polling site on Tuesday morning at a Carnegie Library location in the Pittsburgh area suffered a medical emergency, according to Amie Downs, a spokeswoman for Allegheny County. The individual was hospitalized and voters requested emergency ballots, according to a CNN report.

South Carolina

Voters in South Carolina were seeing a “higher frequency” of calibration issues for voting machines that are around 14 years old, CNN said. That meant that a voter could select a candidate on the screen but might end up choosing the wrong one. Voters should be able to correct their selections when reviewing their choices, however.

The elections director in Richland County, Rokey Suleman, estimated that about 50 of the almost 1,000 machines in the county have had issues. He told CNN that 30 technicians were recalibrating those machines.

Rhode Island

Rhode Island officials delivered a replacement machine by ferry when the sole voting machine on Prudence Island abruptly stopped accepting ballots, Miguel Nunez, the state’s deputy director of elections, told CNN. Voting continued using paper ballots until a new machine was delivered about an hour later.

North Carolina

Machines in several precincts in North Carolina failed to read ballots because of high humidity in some polling places, the Raleigh-based newspaper News and Observer reported. Gary Sims, the Board of Elections director for Wake County, which includes Raleigh, said 15 precincts reported issues earlier in the day, the newspaper reported.

Though GOP Rep. Darrell Issa has been in Congress for 18 years, redistricting and what Issa said were changing political tides in his district make it ripe to turn blue. | Drew Angerer/Getty Images elections Issa forecasts the seat he's vacating will turn blue

Retiring GOP Rep. Darrell Issa on Tuesday conceded that his seat, held by Republicans for nearly two decades, would likely be represented by a Democrat after Election Day.

Before the polls had even opened in his coastal southern California district, Issa appeared on Fox News to prematurely call the race for Democratic candidate Mike Levin.

Story Continued Below

“Quite frankly we know the results already and there will be a Democrat representing La Jolla to Solana Beach for the first time in a number of years," he forecasted.

Though Issa has been in Congress for 18 years, redistricting and what Issa said were changing political tides in his district make it ripe to turn blue. Issa scraped by with a less-than-1-percent margin of victory in 2016 and Hillary Clinton carried the district by 7 points in the presidential race. In California’s so-called jungle primary earlier this year, Democratic candidates garnered a majority of votes in the 49th District.

California is widely viewed as one of the battlegrounds for control of the House in this year's midterms.

“To a certain extent, you have to write off some of California,” he said on Tuesday. “My district was never in play this cycle and so it was never funded.” But Issa predicted that another Republican would hold the seat again someday.

“Someday it’ll be taken back, but for today California is leaning very hard to the left,” he said.

Democrat Josh Harder's campaign is one of two Central Valley races are encompassed by the affected headquarters. | Alex Edelman/Getty Images elections California Democrats rattled by apparent campaign break-in

OAKLAND — California Democrats are raising alarms about an apparent election eve break-in and theft of campaign materials from a party outpost that overlaps with two critical districts.

Campaign officials said workers arrived at the Merced County Senate Democratic headquarters on the morning of Election Day to find that a window had been broken. Computers and dozens of boxes of campaign literature had vanished. A Merced Police Department spokesman did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Story Continued Below

Democrats fear the theft could compromise the results in a pair of swing races that are pivotal to control of Congress and California’s Legislature.

“I’m hopeful this won’t have a huge impact on (get out the vote) efforts but it will obviously have some impact — people are having to divert their attention” from an outlying area to drive materials over, Emily Haden, chairwoman of the Merced County Democratic Central Committee, said by phone. “I really hope this isn’t politically motivated, but given the atmosphere in this county right now it wouldn’t surprise me.”

Two targeted Central Valley races are encompassed by the affected headquarters: Democrat Josh Harder’s challenge to Rep. Jeff Denham (R-Calif.) and a clash between Democratic Assemblywoman Anna Caballero and Republican Madera County Supervisor Rob Poythress over an open state Senate seat that could determine whether Democrats regain a two-thirds majority in the statehouse. That would allow them to raise taxes without Republican votes. Both contests have attracted enormous amounts of money.

“If you were trying to steal an election in what people believe is a fairly close race, and all these things depend at the end of the day on turnout, and you have a highly organized way of distributing thousands of these door-hangers and they’re stolen, it kind of puts a crimp in your operation,” said Bob Sanders, a spokesman for the Caballero campaign.

A Harder campaign representative said they were looking into the situation.

President Donald Trump has warned in the runup to the high-stakes midterms of the potential for election meddling, saying in a tweet yesterday that law enforcement would be watching for “ILLEGAL VOTING which may take place.”

The U.S. Justice Department announced it would be dispatching election monitors to counties around the country, including two in California. Merced County was not one of them.

Carla Marinucci contributed to this report.

Former Vice President Joe Biden has long been on Democrats’ shortlist as a potential challenger against President Donald Trump in 2020. | Scott Olson/Getty Images) elections Biden says it would be 'too early' to announce a presidential run in January

Former Vice President Joe Biden said he still hasn’t decided on running for president in 2020 and won’t confront that question until January.

Speaking to MSNBC reporters on Tuesday morning and shortly after voting in Wilmington, Del., Biden said he would make the decision after Jan. 1 with his family. He wouldn’t announce publicly until later, though he wouldn’t say when exactly that would be.

Story Continued Below

“Oh, I don’t know. It would depend on the circumstances,” Biden said when asked when he would make the announcement. “And a whole lot of things.”

He added that a January announcement would be too early for the next election cycle. “I wouldn’t announce if I were going to run that early. It would be too early to start it,” he said.

Biden has long been on Democrats’ shortlist as a potential challenger against President Donald Trump in 2020. The former vice president has spent the past week crisscrossing the country campaigning for Democratic candidates in Tuesday’s elections. Throughout his appearances, Biden has often stolen the show, denouncing the current Republican party of using paranoid and racist rhetoric to advance its agenda, and saying: “This is not your father’s Republican Party.”

Biden’s frequent appearances have led some to believe that he is building support for a 2020 presidential run. But when an MSNBC reporter asked him if that were the case, Biden demurred and said he had been asked to make appearances for his fellow Democrats.

In his Tuesday interview, Biden also said he would be “dumbfounded” if Democrats don’t reclaim the House, adding they also have a possibility of retaking the Senate. He also added he believes Democrats will win six gubernatorial races in the Midwest and West.

President Donald Trump did not explain where he had heard the rumor, though “Fox and Friends,” one of the president’s favorite shows, claimed that Senate candidate Josh Hawley did not stick around for the rally’s entirety. | Scott Olson/Getty Images elections Trump disputes 'rumor' that Hawley left campaign rally early

President Donald Trump used his first Twitter message of Election Day to hit back at a rumor he said was “deception” on the part of Democrats that Missouri Senate candidate Josh Hawley left a campaign rally headlined by the president Monday night before it was over.

The Cape Girardeau rally was Trump’s last of the midterm campaign and featured singer Lee Greenwood and Fox News personalities Sean Hannity and Jeanine Pirro.

Story Continued Below

“There is a rumor, put out by the Democrats, that Josh Hawley of Missouri left the Arena last night early,” Trump wrote. “It is Fake News. He met me at the plane when I arrived, spoke at the great Rally, & stayed to the very end. In fact, I said goodbye to him and left before he did. Deception!”

The president did not explain where he had heard the rumor, though “Fox & Friends,” one of the president’s favorite shows, claimed that Hawley did not stick around for the rally’s entirety.

“Why Josh Hawley didn't stay last night for the Missouri rally is beyond me,” host Brian Kilmeade said near the top of the show in an explanation of how passionate Trump rallygoers are. “What could he have been doing that was so important?”

A spokesperson for Hawley on Tuesday also disputed that Hawley left the rally early, saying that Hawley accompanied both Trump before, during and after the event.

Hawley is running against Democratic Sen. Claire McCaskill in what the GOP is eyeing as one of its prime pickup opportunities of the cycle, after Trump won the state by 18 points in 2016. POLITICO rates the race as a toss-up.

On Tuesday Hawley retweeted the president's message, claiming that McCaskill's campaign was employing "desperation & dirty tricks to the end."

As we head into the midterms, it seems like our full attention is focused on which party will win control of the House and Senate. But let’s not overlook some of the other issues on state ballots this year—from minimum wage increases in Arkansas and Missouri to recreational marijuana legalization in Michigan and North Dakota.

Statewide initiatives are the closest thing we have in the United States to direct democracy, but they’re also one of the biggest targets of influence spending. Billionaire Democrat and environmental advocate Tom Steyer has poured millions into campaigns to increase the renewable energy mandates in Arizona and Nevada, for example, while opposition to California’s Proposition 8, which would cap revenue at the state’s dialysis clinics, hit a ballot initiative fundraising record of $111 million.

Story Continued Below

In total, there are 155 initiatives across 37 states on the ballot on Tuesday. Here are five of the most interesting ones:

A step toward state bans on abortion

In Alabama and West Virginia, voters will have the chance to amend their respective state constitutions to restrict abortion rights. West Virginia’s proposition would explicitly not protect the right to abortion or state funding of the procedure, while Alabama’s proposition would go one step further by giving rights to fetuses, or, as the proposition states, “unborn children.”

Many believe there’s an explicit strategy here. With the recent confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, anti-abortion advocates are looking forward to the possibility that the court will overturn Roe v. Wade. While these ballot initiatives can’t legally ban abortion while Roe stands, they will, if approved, pave the way for Alabama and West Virginia to constitutionally do so should Roe be overturned. “They’re setting the stage for if and when Roe falls,” West Virginia abortion rights activist Margaret Chapman Pomponio told Politico this summer. Meanwhile, Oregon voters will also decide whether to prohibit the use of public funds (such as for Medicaid recipients or public employees) for abortions, though recent polling suggests that initiative will fail. There are no polls for Alabama or West Virginia’s ballot initiatives.

The first state carbon tax

Washington could become the first state in the nation to adopt a price on carbon dioxide emissions as the state’s voters decide the fate of Initiative Measure No. 1631 (I-1631). The battle over I-1631 has shown just how difficult it is to gain broad support for carbon pricing policy. Two years ago, Washington voters turned down a similar ballot initiative. That 2016 measure, I-732, was designed to be a “revenue neutral” tax—meaning, funds received would be returned via tax cuts to those hit hardest by the new tax—in an attempt to gain bipartisan support. But only 1 in 5 Republicans ended up supporting the measure, while it also lost the support of groups like the Sierra Club and others on the left for not doing enough to help poor people and promote clean energy, and it ultimately failed.

This time, I-1631 has been proposed as a “fee” rather than a “tax” that would start at $15 per ton of carbon dioxide in 2020 and increase by $2 per year (plus inflation) until 2035. Should it go into effect, its revenue would be specifically dedicated to environmental and clean energy projects. Though the opposing sides on I-1631 have fallen along more traditionally partisan lines—Bill Gates and Michael Bloomberg have each contributed $1 million in support while BP and Koch Industries have donated millions in opposition—recent polling in the state shows it to be on course to pass. If it does, it won’t make much of a dent in the global climate crisis on its own, but it will be a monumental step forward in state-level action at a time when the president has made it clear that climate change is not a federal policy priority.

A plan to expand rent control

In California, voters will decide whether to repeal a state law that prevents local governments from imposing many forms of rent control. California has an acute housing affordability crisis, and proponents of Proposition 10 see expanding rent control as a potential solution to that problem. But opponents say that there’s no guarantee more rent control would solve the state’s housing woes, and that it could even worsen the problem by disincentivizing the building of new units.

But the issue isn’t partisan. A legislative attempt to do the same thing as this measure failed earlier this year in Sacramento, despite California’s Democratic supermajority, and now the proposition has divided the state’s top Democrats: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti supports it, while Lt. Governor and likely soon-to-be-Governor Gavin Newsom warns that it could have “unintended consequences on housing production that could be profoundly problematic.”

The opposition spending, unsurprisingly, is mostly rooted in a worried renting industry. A landowners association described the proposition as an “existential threat.” And recent polling suggests the outcome may go their way, with 60 percent of likely voters saying they will vote against.

Letting felons vote again

Florida is one of four states (along with Iowa, Kentucky and Virginia) in which people with felony convictions are disenfranchised—even after the completion of their sentences—unless they apply directly to the governor to have their voting rights restored. In Florida, however, that could be about to change. With Amendment 4 on the ballot on Tuesday, voters in the Sunshine State could opt to automatically restore the voting rights of people with prior felony convictions (except those convicted of murder or felony sexual offense) who have completed their sentences. That would mean about 1.5 million new voters, expanding Florida’s current voting population by 10 percent. The latest polls show upward of 70 percent of the state’s likely voters support this amendment.

The 10 Commandments

It was almost exactly 15 years ago when Roy Moore was removed from the bench as chief justice of Alabama’s Supreme Court for defying a federal court order to remove a 5,280-pound granite monument of the Ten Commandments that he had installed in the state’s judicial building. The federal judges who ordered Moore to remove the monument found that it violated the First Amendment’s Establishment Clause, which prohibits government from favoring any religion over another.

Now, Alabama voters will decide whether to amend the state’s constitution to allow specifically the Ten Commandments to be displayed on government property, including public schools and courthouses. Even if the amendment passes, though there hasn’t been any polling on the initiative, it would likely be challenged in federal court. But proponents told the New York Times in September they look forward to that possibility, hoping that a majority conservative Supreme Court might rule in favor of such religious demonstrations.

Ruairí Arrieta-Kenna is a news assistant at Politico Magazine.

Facebook suspended 115 accounts believed to be engaged in "coordinated inauthentic behavior" just before polls opened for Election Day. | Alexander Koerner/Getty Images election cybersecurity Facebook suspends 115 accounts for 'inauthentic behavior' as polls open

Facebook announced late Monday the suspension of 115 accounts it believed to be engaged in "coordinated inauthentic behavior" as top law enforcement officials warned that Russia may still try to interfere in U.S. elections.

The social media giant said it had opened a probe into the accounts to determine whether they were linked to the Russia-based Internet Research Agency, an organization special counsel Robert Mueller named in a February indictment for allegedly attempting to sway U.S. public opinion. In a blog post, Facebook head of cybersecurity policy Nathaniel Gleicher said the company was tipped off to the Facebook and Instagram accounts, which operated in Russian, French and English, by law enforcement.

Story Continued Below

"Typically, we would be further along with our analysis before announcing anything publicly," Gleicher wrote. "But given that we are only one day away from important elections in the US, we wanted to let people know about the action we’ve taken and the facts as we know them today."

The heads of U.S. intelligence and national security also issued a statement in the hours before polls opened, assuring the public that the Tuesday elections were secure, but urging Americans to remain vigilant to possible influence campaigns. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats and FBI Director Christopher Wray said they had "no indication" that a foreign entity could "prevent voting, change vote counts, or disrupt the ability to tally votes."

"But Americans should be aware that foreign actors — and Russia in particular — continue to try to influence public sentiment and voter perceptions through actions intended to sow discord," the agency heads wrote. "They can do this by spreading false information about political processes and candidates, lying about their own interference activities, disseminating propaganda on social media, and through other tactics."

Social media companies have ramped up coordination with law enforcement to prevent foreign influence campaigns aimed at interfering in the U.S. democratic process. Facebook, Twitter and Google acknowledged to Congress in February that the Internet Research Agency created thousands of accounts on their sites, reaching American users through posts and paid ads.

Two weeks ago, Facebook purged 82 Iranian-originated accounts for posting about race relations, opposition to President Donald Trump and immigration while presenting themselves as American or British citizens. The social network has also opened an "elections war room" to discover and investigate malign activity.

Tax writers play major role in Congress' fate

BALANCE OF POWER: If there’s a political realignment in the Capitol by the end of today, Congress’ two tax-writing committees could play an outsize role. An unusually large number of House Ways and Means incumbents are in competitive races this year, and several Senate Finance members are in marquee races. Here’s your scorecard for watching the returns.

Story Continued Below

Rep. Peter Roskam (R-Ill.): POLITICO’s analysis of competitive races has Roskam’s district in the “lean Democrat” category as he fights to hold on against Democrat Sean Casten. Hillary Clinton won the district by 7 points in 2016. Roskam chaired the tax policy subcommittee before taking over the health subcommittee in January.

Rep. Erik Paulsen (R-Minn.): He’s also in a “lean Democrat” district, facing off against Democrat Dean Phillips. Paulsen was re-elected in 2016 “despite President Trump losing his district by a significant margin. But Trump’s numbers there have gotten worse, and Paulsen trailed Democrat Dean Phillips by 9 points in a recent New York Times/Siena College poll,” our race analysts note.

Rep. Mike Bishop (R-Mich.): Another “lean Democrat” race. Democrats consider his challenger, Elissa Slotkin, a former CIA officer and Pentagon official, "one of the party's top recruits,” our analysis says.

Rep. Carlos Curbelo (R-Fla.): Curbelo’s race against Democrat Debbie Mucarsel-Powell is a toss-up. Curbelo seemed like a good bet for re-election earlier this year — he won with 53 percent of the vote in 2016 in a district Clinton carried by 16, our political aces noted. But the candidates are now in a dead heat, polls show.

Rep. George Holding (R-N.C.): This is another “toss-up” race. Though Trump carried the district by 10 points, three recent polls showed Holding neck and neck with Democrat Linda Coleman.

Rep. Jackie Walorski (R-Ind.): POLITICO recently moved this race to “lean Republican” from “likely Republican.” “Democrats will be watching the first returns from this district — where … Walorski faces a well-funded Democratic challenger, Mel Hall — for an early read on the national environment on election night,” our analysts say.

Rep. Mike Kelly (R-Pa.): POLITICO also moved this race to “lean” from “likely” Republican, noting that Democrats added it to their national target list. PoliticsPA said Kelly’s race against Democrat Ron DiNicola “appears to be a last-breaking sleeper.”

Rep. Vern Buchanan (R-Fla.): POLITICO moved this race to “likely” from “lean” Republican. “Democrats had hoped to knock off GOP Rep. Vern Buchanan, but the six-term incumbent appears to be on more solid ground at the close of the campaign,” our analysts said. Buchanan, who took over the tax policy subcommittee from Roskam, is facing Democrat David Shapiro.

Over at Senate Finance there are fewer seats in play, but they will be crucial to determining the political fate of the chamber:

Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-Mo.): Her race against Republican Josh Hawley is rated a “toss-up.” McCaskill is trying to hang on in a state that Trump carried by 19 points.

Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.): Another “toss-up” in a state won by Trump, but only by 1.2 percentage points. “The race between Nelson and [Republican Rick] Scott could set records as the most expensive Senate election of all time,” according to POLITICO’s analysis.

Sen. Dean Heller (R-Nev.): The third “toss-up,” as Heller tries to fend off a challenge from Democratic Rep. Jacky Rosen. “Nevada is the only GOP-held Senate seat up this cycle in a state Hillary Clinton won in 2016,” our experts note.

Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.): This could be a Republican pick up. POLITICO has moved the race to “lean” from “likely” Democrat. “Republican Bob Hugin continues to pummel … Menendez over the incumbent’s graft trial last year, which resulted in a mistrial. A series of recent polls pegged Menendez’s lead anywhere between just 2 points, and a more comfortable 11 points.”

DIGITAL DELAY: The EU won’t have a deal on a digital tax proposal before December, French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire says. That’s because France and Germany aren’t seeing eye to eye on the issue yet. French President Emmanuel “Macron’s team wants the European Union to adopt a tax that would mainly target companies like Google and Facebook, which generate much of their income via targeted online advertising,” POLITICO Europe’s Nicholas Vinocur reports. “Draft proposals suggest the tax would amount to 3 percent of a company’s revenue and only target those with more than €750 million [$856 million] in annual revenue, for a total Europe-wide take of about €5 billion [$5.7 billion]. But Germany has been cool on the idea, citing concerns about potential U.S. retaliation, double taxation, and competitiveness.”

Meanwhile, Moody’s is warning about the effect Britain’s proposed digital services tax would have on the credit ratings of Facebook, Google and other Big Tech companies. “The implementation of such a tax would be credit negative for these and other digital information companies because it would reduce free cash flow generation and scale back the tax benefits achieved through the US Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017,” Moody’s Senior Vice President Neil Begley and analyst Vincent Tingos said in a note to clients.

ANOTHER SHOT AT AMAZON: Critics of the massive, secretive incentive packages that cities reportedly have offered to Amazon for its second headquarters got some new ammunition when The Wall Street Journal reported that the retail giant plans to split the digs evenly between two locations. The Free and Fair Markets Initiative, which styles itself as a tech industry watchdog, didn’t mince any words, calling it a “bait and switch.”

“Amazon asked cities for massive tax breaks and subsidies in return for a headquarters, but in the eleventh hour they are going back on their word and taking half the deal off the table,” Robert B. Engel, the group’s chief spokesperson, said in a statement. “Now they are asking taxpayers in two states to cough up their hard-earned money for a fraction of what was promised.”

INTERNATIONAL UPDATE

GE IN THE CROSSHAIRS: U.K. tax authorities are alleging the country has been bilked by an interest deduction claimed by GE Capital, the company’s financial services arm. “HM Revenue & Customs is pursuing General Electric for almost £800 million [$1 billion] in tax deductions going back 14 years,” the Times of London reports. GE vowed to fight the decision. “If assessed, we intend to contest the disallowance,” the company said in an SEC filing. “We comply with all applicable tax laws and judicial doctrines of the UK.”

STATE NEWS

COUGHING UP THE DOUGH: Tobacco companies have spent about $85 per smoker in Montana to defeat a ballot initiative that would raise the tobacco tax to ensure funding for a Medicaid expansion. “Fearing legislators might not renew funding for Medicaid's expanded rolls, Montana's hospitals and other health advocacy groups have come up with a ballot measure to keep it going — and to pay for it with a tobacco tax,” NPR reports. Enter the tobacco companies. “The tobacco tax initiative has become the most expensive ballot measure race in Montana history — drawing more than $17 million in opposition funding from tobacco companies alone — in a state with fewer than 200,000 smokers,” NPR said.

SUNNY REAL ESTATE MARKETS: Nevada and Florida may be prime beneficiaries of a surge in real estate investment from abroad as a result of new tax regulations. “We’ve seen a lot of spark in 2018 because of the new tax codes,” Don Pingaro, a partner and real estate broker at ISG, said at a panel discussion in Miami, according to Urban Land magazine. “People are domiciling in Nevada and Florida because of lax tax laws.” He also said that international investments in the U.S. market are being driven by politics, including election results in Mexico and Colombia.

DID YOU KNOW?

Plying voters with liquor was once a common practice. “George Washington’s entire campaign budget for his 1758 election to the House of Burgesses was spent on liquor,” according to Farmers’ Almanac. A darker side of the practice may have played a role in Edgar Allan Poe’s 1849 death in Baltimore. Some experts believe that Poe was a victim of “cooping” — basically kidnapped, forced to drink sometimes enormous quantities of liquor and carried from polling place to polling place to vote repeatedly.

WAITING IN THE WINGS: To pull you away from repeatedly refreshing election news, here’s our spin on an idea from POLITICO Playbook: Given the strong possibility that Democrats will win a majority in the House next year for the first time since 2010, MT put together a list of some of the Democratic staffers who could be key to shaping transportation and infrastructure policy in the 116th Congress.



On T&I: Kathy Dedrick, a long-time Hill staffer who also worked for former Vice President Al Gore for four years, is staff director for Democrats on the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee. Kristie Greco Johnson is ranking member Peter DeFazio’s chief of staff; she has also worked for assistant minority leader Jim Clyburn (D-S.C.) in addition to a stint at the FAA. The top Democratic staffers on the T&I subcommittees could also be important players: Rachel Devine, staff director of the Aviation subpanel, Dave Jansen, staff director on the Coast Guard Subcommittee, Helena Zyblikewycz on Highways and Transit, and Elizabeth Hill on Railroads and Pipelines.

Approps, etc: The top Democratic staffer on the House Appropriations Transportation-HUD Subcommittee is Joe Carlile, and Darek Newby (who’s also worked for likely THUD Chairman David Price) is the lead on the Homeland Security subpanel. Hope Goins heads up minority staff on the Homeland Security Committee, and Alex Marston is the minority staff director of the Transportation and Protective Security Subcommittee. Over on Energy and Commerce, which regularly works on transportation issues including electric vehicles, Jeff Carroll is the Democratic staff director.

Don’t forget: To read our Tanya Snyder’s story on DeFazio, the potential next T&I chairman, who has a deep understanding of transportation issues and is gearing up to conduct oversight on the Trump administration.

ROLL TO THE POLLS: Lime is offering two free rides on its bikes around the U.S. to help voters with Election Day transportation (use the code LIME2VOTE18). MT told you last week that Motivate, the bikeshare company that operates in nine major cities, is also giving away free rides. And The Washington Post has a roundup of free or discounted options around the country.

AUTOMOBILES

PUSHING FOR SCHOOL BUS IMPROVEMENTS: Safety advocates are asking Congress to take up a bill aimed at making school buses safer in the wake of recent crashes in several states that have killed five children and injured dozens of people. Introduced in September, the legislation, S. 3432 (115), would require buses to have seat belts in every seat, use technology like automatic emergency braking and electronic stability control, and carry an event data recorder. “We laud the leadership of Senator Tammy Duckworth (D-IL) and Representative Steve Cohen (D-TN) for introducing this lifesaving, commonsense bill and urge Congress to take action on it immediately,” said Cathy Chase, president of Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety, in a statement. The bill, which is based on recommendations from NTSB, has not advanced in either the House or Senate.

TESLA UPDATE: The on-site medical clinic at Tesla Inc.’s assembly plant in California has failed to properly care for seriously injured workers, according to a new exposé by Reveal from the Center for Investigative Reporting. Will Evans reports that medical staff need permission to call 911 and are often denied, and hurt workers are regularly sent back to the production line to work through pain. When workers are sent to the hospital, it’s often in a Lyft instead of an ambulance. Five former clinic employees said its practices are unsafe and unethical. The company declined to comment to Reveal.

Aviation

HOLDING DOWN THE FORT: Per Reuters’ David Shepardson, acting FAA administrator Dan Elwell joked Monday that his days on the job are numbered following a report from The Wall Street Journal that the administration has settled on Delta executive Steve Dickson as a consensus pick for the agency’s top job. Elwell did not directly address whether he is still in contention to head FAA on a permanent basis, according to Shepardson’s tweet.

Rail

WYOMING PROBE ONGOING: The rear brakes of a Union Pacific freight train did not respond to normal and emergency braking in a Wyoming crash that killed two crewmembers last month, Tanya reports. NTSB is still investigating the collision between a moving and stationary train, which derailed dozens of cars and three locomotives.

Security

STARTING ROSTER: TSA has approved 12 organizations to provide third-party certifications of bomb-sniffing dogs for its air cargo screening program, per a notice published in the Federal Register today. The certifiers are required to follow TSA standards for certifying canines to screen both domestic and foreign air cargo. Selected third-party dog certifiers were permitted to start certifying dog teams on Nov. 1, according to the notice. The FAA reauthorization, H.R. 302 (115), also includes a number of provisions aimed at boosting TSA’s canine stock, including a mandate for the agency to establish a list of third-party domestic dog breeders to help curtail the agency’s reliance on foreign-bred dogs.

ON TAP TODAY: U.S. midterm elections today could lead to a change in party leadership in the House — meaning Democrats might have a role to play in USMCA passage and oversight of new trade negotiations. Chinese President Xi Jinping is pledging China will import more goods and services over the next 15 years. And the departing Mexican president shares his thoughts on how the NAFTA negotiations went. Let’s dig in:

WHAT WE’RE WATCHING IN TONIGHT’S RESULTS: Voters are heading to the polls across the country today to cast ballots in roughly three dozen Senate and gubernatorial races and in House races in every congressional district. The outcomes could dictate how much trade becomes a focus in Congress in several ways:

NAFTA 2.0 on deck: The biggest-ticket item on the legislative agenda next year will be passing the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, now that lame-duck passage has essentially been ruled out. If Democrats take over the House, they will likely look to leave their mark on the agreement in some way — perhaps by insisting on changes in the implementing bill to further tighten labor standards.

They might be loath to hand President Donald Trump a policy victory on one of his top priorities. But U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer’s dedication during talks to keeping in close touch with labor representatives means there’s a lot for Democrats to like in the deal, analysts contend.

Natural allies of Democrats, like prominent environmental groups, have come out against the deal. But voting down NAFTA 2.0 risks economic turmoil — especially with the 2020 presidential election on the horizon. For a refresher on where House Democrats might be able to work with the White House, including on NAFTA, click here.

New negotiations: The Trump administration is also looking to move forward on negotiations with the European Union, Japan and the U.K.

In those negotiations and any others, “adherence to [Trade Promotion Authority] is going to be something that Democrats are going to insist on,” Democratic strategist and lobbyist John Michael Gonzalez told Morning Trade. Gonzalez noted that Democrats have not been shy in the past about making their concerns about ongoing negotiations known even when they were working with a president from their own party.

“If they weren’t shy about holding President Obama accountable, they’re certainly not going to be shy in holding President Trump accountable,” he said. “When the Democrats are displeased about how negotiations are going, it doesn’t matter who’s in the White House.”

Here’s an hour-by-hour guide to watching tonight’s results like a pro.

That means that if control of the House depends on how Golden State races turn out — well, it could be a while until we find out which party will take control of the speaker’s gavel next year. More on that here.

XI MAKES FRESH REFORM PROMISES: Chinese President Xi Jinping on Monday promised to further open up China’s economy, just weeks ahead of his expected meeting with Trump at the G-20 meeting in Buenos Aires. He made the comments at the inaugural China International Import Expo, an event created by Beijing to signal its plans to increase trade.

The pledge to buy more products and services from abroad is "not a temporary arrangement but a long-term consideration," Xi said. China will buy $30 trillion of foreign goods and $10 trillion of foreign services over the next 15 years; it will also open up its health care, education, financial services, telecommunications and mining sectors to foreign investors, Xi said.

Xi said “the right things,” Erin Ennis, vice president at the U.S.-China Business Council, told Morning Trade. “But we need to see implementation for it to address business concerns.” Click here to read the full story from our partners at the South China Morning Post.

Fact-check: Caixin Media, an independent business news publication, crunched the numbers and found that based on current import data, China will be able to meet Xi’s goals by hardly doing a thing.

Beijing imported $1.84 trillion in goods last year, so it would import about $27.6 trillion over the next 15 years even if imports do not increase at all. But Caixin warns that’s a conservative estimate: Goods imports jumped nearly 16 percent from 2016 to 2017 alone.

IRAN VOWS TO BREAK NEW U.S. SANCTIONS: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani pledged Monday that his country would not buckle under the weight of fresh U.S. sanctions on its oil and banking sectors. Iran will “proudly break the sanctions” that went into effect at midnight as a result of Trump’s decision to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal, Rouhani said in a televised address.

ALUMINUM GROUPS CALL FOR REPEAL OF TARIFFS: North American aluminum associations joined forces to call on Trump to remove his tariffs on aluminum from Canada and Mexico before the three countries sign a new trade agreement by the end of the month. The appeal came in a letter to leaders of the three countries, as well as Mexican President-elect Andrés Manuel López Obrador. “The USMCA cannot work for the aluminum industry or our many downstream customers without exempting Canada and Mexico from the 232 tariffs or quotas,” they said.

TRUMP’S SEPTEMBER TARIFF TOLL HITS $1.4B: U.S. companies paid an estimated $1.4 billion in additional duties in September on steel, aluminum and a wide array of Chinese goods as a result of actions taken by Trump, according to a new analysis by Tariffs Hurt the Heartland, an anti-tariff advocacy group.

Importers paid $1.8 billion in tariffs on products hit by Trump’s tariffs during September, compared with a mere $393 million in the same month last year. That was despite an 11 percent decline in the value of imports, the group said.

A number likely to rise: The latest figures don’t reflect the 10 percent tariff the administration imposed on an additional $200 billion worth of Chinese goods on Sept. 24, a group spokesman, former Rep. Charles Boustany, said in a statement. Those duties will rise to 25 percent on Jan. 1.

PEÑA NIETO’S PERSPECTIVE ON NAFTA TALKS: Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto and other officials showered each other with high praise on Monday for successfully reaching a new North American trade pact. Peña Nieto also recognized López Obrador and his designated chief NAFTA negotiator, Jesús Seade, for their work in helping to create a united front between the current and incoming administrations.

Speaking at an event held at the his official residence, Los Pinos, Peña Nieto credited his controversial meeting with then-candidate Trump in 2016 for helping to “leave the door open” for Mexico to work on addressing Trump’s harsh positions.

Peña Nieto wasn’t shy to acknowledge that negotiations often got heated. He added that some of those tense moments have been discussed publicly or leaked to the media, but others will remain secret. “This whole process was loaded with many episodes — a lot more than what you’d imagine,” he said.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

— The Trump administration's highest-ranking private sector advisory committee has endorsed USMCA and is calling on Congress to approve the deal, POLITICO Pro reports.

— Alibaba’s Jack Ma says the U.S.-China trade war is the “most stupid thing in the world,” the South China Morning Post reports.

— U.S. pork exports to Mexico have fallen in value in the face of Mexico's retaliatory tariffs, while European and Canadian pork producers are seizing the opportunity, POLITICO Pro reports.

— An Ohio retailer is offering a “pre-tariff” sale on appliances and furniture that he says reflects prices before the negative effects of the current trade climate began to set in, the Toledo Blade reports.

— An EU-Japan trade deal cleared a major procedural hurdle and is on its way to take effect in 2019, VOA reports.

— China’s vice president says Beijing remains open to discussing a solution on trade with the U.S., Bloomberg reports.

Making sense of the Georgia ‘cyber crime’

With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak, Christian Vasquez and Cristiano Lima

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

SUSSING OUT THE GEORGIA KERFUFFLE — The Georgia cybersecurity incident has rocketed to the top of the headlines in the final days before the election. Republican Secretary of State Brian Kemp, in a tight gubernatorial race, opened an investigation over the weekend after alleging the Democratic Party of Georgia tried to hack into the state voter registration system — charges that the party and others say are ginned up as a distraction. Kemp’s Democratic opponent Stacey Abrams called it “a witch hunt.”

Now, the Georgia Bureau of Investigation has followed suit on its own probe. “The GBI has been requested by the Secretary of State to investigate allegations of computer crimes related to the Secretary of State's website(s),” the bureau said in a statement Monday to MC. “A criminal investigation will be conducted by the GBI's Georgia Cyber Crime Center.”

Democrats say that not only is Kemp trying to distract voters, but he also has it wrong. Emails shared by both the Democratic party and Kemp’s office show that a volunteer, Rachel Small, forwarded an email to the party detailing a My Voter page vulnerability or vulnerabilities. Democrats separately shared an email demonstrating that Small was forwarding an email from Richard Wright, a private citizen.

A Democratic party official, Sara Ghazal, then forwarded Small’s email to two Georgia Tech professors, Wenke Lee and Rich DeMillo. Lee serves on a Kemp-created election commission and DeMillo forwarded the email to an attorney for the Coalition for Good Governance, which is suing Georgia over its use of paperless voting machines. That attorney forwarded the email to outside counsel for Kemp’s office. Ghazal said in her email that she feared it was a dangerous vulnerability.

Here’s what Candice Broce, a spokesperson for Kemp, told MC: “What we saw in the correspondence was a plan for action and the accompanying computer program to execute the plan.” Broce also said the email aroused her office’s suspicion because Ghazal regularly communicates with the secretary of state team and this time did not share the information directly.

But the forwarded email from Small does not, by MC’s reading, describe a plan so much as a possibility for anyone with the know-how — it discusses something that “can” be done, not something that will or should. All of the email correspondence reviewed by MC shows that those who received forwarded email were either grateful to get the information or neutrally passed it along further.

Nonetheless, it was enough for Kemp’s office to open an inquiry. Under Georgia law, “I’m not sure you have to have someone successfully hack a system for it to be a cybercrime, especially when talking about systems like ours” that have an elevated level of priority, Broce said. Georgia’s incumbent governor this summer vetoed legislation opposed by security researchers who said it would make even probing for vulnerabilities illegal.

— VULNERABILITY OR NAH?: Kemp’s office says there is no vulnerability like the one described in Small’s forwarded email. “Based on the information we have we were not able to recreate or substantiate any of the vulnerabilities he alleged,” Broce said, citing a review that included outside cybersecurity experts. Kemp himself referred to a “potential vulnerability” on Monday. Other cybersecurity experts who have reviewed the situation have opined that the vulnerability is troublesome, but in at least one case Broce said the story was erroneous, and some of the experts said they did not want to try to test the “worst” vulnerability further for fear of running afoul of cybercrime laws.

Lee declined to comment to MC, saying his commission work “does not include examining allegations of vulnerabilities in the present system,” and referred questions to DeMillo. “It's a genuine vulnerability,” DeMillo told MC, who said he assumed Kemp’s office had already learned of the issue by the time he forwarded the email, and pointed to other correspondence showing the FBI had been alerted. DeMillo was confused by Kemp’s response. “The idea that these URLs that were in the [attached] file would somehow be confused with a script or attack, I don't understand that,” he said.

HAPPY TUESDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! The new test of optimist versus pessimist: Is this monkey a good monkey, or a scammer who perpetuates crime to win credit for solving it? KREMLIN MIXING IT UP — Russian social media operations aimed at inflaming partisan views ahead of the midterms have worked harder in recent weeks to appear more legitimate, according to the cybersecurity firm Recorded Future. “While we believe that we have identified only a portion of the full scale of the operation, important trends have emerged that may be applicable to larger Russian operations targeting the United States,” Priscilla Moriuchi, director of strategic threat development, said in a statement on Monday. The Kremlin’s influence operations have “evolved since 2016” and the “content propagated by these operations has shifted focus from verifiably false information (or ‘fake news’) to hyperpartisan perspectives.”

MOMENT OF TRUTH FOR SOCIAL MEDIA — For months, tech companies have touted strides they’ve made since 2016 in their election security efforts — and that progress is already getting tested as today’s midterms kick off. Late Monday night, Facebook’s Nathaniel Gleicher announced the company was alerted by U.S. law enforcement authorities on Sunday to online activity “they believe may be linked to foreign entities.” Through a preliminary investigation, the company unearthed 30 accounts on Facebook and 85 on Instagram that “may be engaged in coordinated inauthentic behavior.” The company could not initially say whether the efforts were tied to the notorious “Russia-based Internet Research Agency or other foreign entities,” Gleicher added.

Though the full extent of the suspected propaganda campaign remains unclear, how U.S. authorities and the company respond to its discovery will offer a glimpse into how far both sides have come since 2016. Earlier Monday, spokesman Andy Stone told Morning Tech that staffers at Facebook HQ are in “direct contact with the Department of Homeland Security” regarding their efforts to curb misinformation. The federal agency is one of several planning its own “war room” to tackle election-related issues. Twitter and Reddit, meanwhile, said they’ve also been working closely with DHS, with Twitter adding it’s meeting “regularly” with the agency ahead of Election Day.

CONGRESSMAN HACKED, BUT NOT LIKE THAT — The campaign Twitter account for the top Democrat on the Energy and Commerce Committee, which plays a big role in cybersecurity-related legislation, got hacked Monday, Twitter confirmed. But the attack on the account of Rep. Frank Pallone doesn’t appear to be politically motivated, the social media company said. The hackers altered Pallone’s site to identify him as Tesla CEO Elon Musk and promote a cryptocurrency giveaway. Pallone’s campaign did not answer requests for comment from MC.

SPAMMERS FIND MORE SUCCESS THAN TRUMP STEAKS — Spammers are leaning on the Trump brand. Research out Monday from Proofpoint analyzing a month’s worth of spam subject lines focused on politics found that “Trump” appeared nearly five times as often as the next most common term, “Democrat.” Concluded ProofPoint: “As we have repeatedly found in recent elections — and more generally in the spam landscape — spam actors rely on strong brands to generate clicks.”

WYDEN: PAPER BALLOTS, PLEASE — Sen. Ron Wyden said it again on Monday: Make paper ballots available to all voters and give them the ability to send in votes by mail. Citing a POLITICO report of voting machine glitches in Georgia and Texas, Wyden urged lawmakers to support the PAVE Act (S. 3049), the bill he introduced to make paper ballots and voting from home the standard on election days. In a statement, he said this election cycle “put a spotlight on the fact that too many voters are stuck with glitchy, insecure voting machines that are hard to use and easy to hack.” So far, the bill has no Republican cosponsors but has the backing of election integrity advocates, and it’s gained momentum after the Secure Elections Act (S. 2593) stalled due to GOP opposition.

FROM FASHION TO ELECTION EQUIPMENT — Ivanka Trump won initial approval in China for a range of trademarks, including voting machines, a watchdog group revealed Monday. The watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington raised an eyebrow at the voting machines given the probes into Russian election interference and the president, said spokesman Jordan Libowitz. “A lot of the other things make sense, like Ivanka Trump brand sausages — there are Jimmy Dean sausages,” Libowitz told MC. “An Ivanka brand voting machine?” An attorney representing the president’s daughter did not respond to a request for comment.

ON THE RIGHT TRACK — The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is improving its cybersecurity posture across the board but still needs to define its risk tolerance level and improve its mobile device patching process, according to a new audit by the inspector general of the Federal Reserve System, which houses the CFPB. The report also warned the CFPB to restrict access to an internal software platform that contained personally identifiable information, and it recommended changes to how the agency protects its databases and fixes vulnerabilities. The CFPB’s chief information officer agreed with auditors’ recommendations and pledged to implement them.

Auditors had an equally positive review of the Federal Reserve’s board of governors, which they described as operating at a “managed and measurable” level of cybersecurity maturity. But like its assessment of the CFPB, the IG’s office dinged the Fed for a “lack of an agencywide risk management governance structure and strategy,” saying, “several security processes, such as asset management and enterprise architecture, have not yet been implemented agencywide.” It noted that the board of governors had fixed four of the 13 recommendations from the IG’s 2017 audit. In addition to the remaining nine recommendations, the IG added six new ones covering risk management and security training.

SHARING IS CARING — U.S. Cyber Command's Cyber Mission Force posted its first malware sample to VirusTotal, a Google-owned malware intelligence database. “Recognizing the value of collaboration with the public sector, the CNMF has initiated an effort to share unclassified malware samples it has discovered that it believes will have the greatest impact on improving global cybersecurity,” Cyber Command said in a statement Monday.

MORE ‘HACK THE’ — The Air Force is ready to be hacked again, on purpose. HackerOne is its teammate once more for the bug bounty initiative “Hack the Air Force 3.0.” That’s the biggest number of hacking events for a part of the military, and 191 countries are now eligible to participate, more than ever before. The event, focusing on Air Force apps recently migrated over to its cloud, ends Nov. 22.

TWEET OF THE DAY — You heard the man!

Spotlight on patient safety

With help from Arthur Allen (@arthurallen202) and Darius Tahir (@dariustahir)

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning eHealth is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro eHealth subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

SPOTLIGHT ON PATIENT SAFETY: This month’s issue of Health Affairs featured several studies on patient safety. Here are a few of our takeaways:

Greater risk to kids: Poor EHR design can lead to medication errors, which can be especially detrimental for children whose body weights are lower and whose immune systems aren’t as developed as adults’. In more than a third of pediatric patient safety events involving EHRs and medication, the technology’s “usability” contributed to medication errors, according to one study.

For instance, one physician ordered five times the recommended dosage without getting an alert from the EHR, researchers found.

In about a fifth of those cases, the mistake — which could result in improper dosage or incorrect prescriptions — actually reached the patient, sometimes leading to temporary harm, according to the analysis of 9,000 safety reports.

Raj Ratwani — director of the National Center for Human Factors in Healthcare at MedStar Health and the study's lead author — has urged ONC to publish a draft of a voluntary certification for EHRs used in pediatric settings; the 21st Century Cures Act directs ONC to create those criteria.

Researchers also argued that Congress should conduct oversight into ONC’s plan to create an EHR reporting program that could help customers compare products, ensuring that the agency is prioritizing patient safety.

—Why health systems should just ask patients what went wrong: Perhaps unsurprisingly, patient feedback can help physicians better understand their mistakes, researchers concluded in another study. After examining almost 200 patient narratives describing diagnostic error, researchers found 224 mentions of interpersonal and behavioral factors that could have contributed to the error — doctors ignoring patient knowledge or disrespecting patients, for instance.

Health systems have a rigorous process for analyzing diagnostic error, but it doesn’t often involve the patient’s own experience, said lead author Traber Giardina, a researcher at the Center for Innovations in Quality, Effectiveness, and Safety.

Giardina told Morning eHealth that hospital systems should establish an IT system that can gather patient feedback in a way patients feel is convenient, such as a mobile app.

“Right now, there are no good ways to get data electronically from patients except maybe patient experience surveys,” said Hardeep Singh, a researcher and medical professor at Baylor University.

Once health systems gather more patient narratives, they could use natural language processing and sentiment analysis to quickly look for factors that could have led to diagnostic error, Singh added.

There might even be hints about diagnostic error buried within common patient complaints about parking, temperature and food, Singh said. “In their narrative, did they really talk about a misdiagnosis?”

Real-time warnings: Researchers have piloted a way of monitoring EHRs to detect safety risks to hospitalized patients in real time. Pascal Metrics says it is the first organization to apply machine learning to a dataset of EHR-based adverse event outcomes.

The system, which Pascal tested at two community hospitals, can detect patient harm from real-time data and fires triggers that result in patient safety monitoring.

"This appears to be a genuine pivot away from retrospective reviews of patient safety incidents to real-time analysis," said Jeff Smith, vice president for public policy at the American Medical Informatics Association.

While the study demonstrates the potential for use of real-time data, there were many false positives triggered by the system, noted Dean Sittig, a professor of bioinformatics at the University of Texas Health Sciences Center in Houston.

Until EHR systems become capable of limiting these false alarms, "systems like these will be untenable for all but the highest-staffed facilities," Sittig said. Pros can read the rest of the story on the studies here.

VA EHR HEARING SET FOR NEXT WEEK: The House Veterans' Affairs subcommittee overseeing the VA's Electronic Health Record Modernization will hold a hearing next Wednesday to review the first 180 days of the Cerner contract, Morning eHealth’s Arthur Allen reports. Ranking Member Tim Walz noted recent reporting by POLITICO and ProPublica on problems and infighting at the VA that imperil the success of the project. Pros can read the full story here.

SUPREME COURT DECLINES TO TAKE NET NEUTRALITY CASE: The court battle over now-repealed Obama-era net neutrality rules ended with the Supreme Court declining to take the case.

According to a court order, Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch would have vacated a 2016 D.C. Circuit Court opinion upholding the regulations, which banned the blocking, slowing or paid prioritization of web traffic.

But Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Brett Kavanaugh "took no part in the consideration or decision of these petitions," denying challengers the conservative majority they needed to take the case and reverse the lower court decision.

Telemedicine advocates have argued that the repeal of net neutrality regulations could limit patients’ and providers’ access to virtual treatment.

RESMED BUYS EHR COMPANY MATRIXCARE: Respiratory device company ResMed acquired EHR vendor MatrixCare for $750 million, MobiHealthNews reports.

Today’s the day … It’s the final countdown, folks, and tonight we’ll finally see how President Donald Trump’s immigration messaging and unions’ mobilization efforts have swayed voters in this year’s midterms.

Here’s what we know: POLITICO’s final race ratings anticipate Democrats will gain between 25 and 40 House seats — more than the 23 pickups they need to take the majority.

“A Democratic-controlled House — nearly unthinkable earlier this decade, given the GOP’s structural advantages in the way the districts are drawn — would represent a rebuke to Trump, even with a booming economy, and grind much of his legislative agenda to a halt until the 2020 election,” writes POLITICO’s Steven Shepard.

Republicans are expected to hold on to their Senate majority.

IMMIGRATION

TIME TO WALK THE WALK: Trump turned the midterms into a referendum on his immigration policies with a series of dramatic moves in recent weeks, including dispatching 5,200 troops to the southwest border and suggesting he could issue an executive order to roll back birthright citizenship. But how will the immigration tough talk play out? Here are some races to watch:

The ‘immigration reducers’: Nonprofit NumbersUSA, which advocates for reduced levels of immigration, published a list of House races it’s watching. The lawmakers with “top immigration reduction ratings” in competitive campaigns include Reps. Scott Perry (R-Pa.), Pete Sessions (R-Texas) and Dave Brat (R-Va.).

The Trump allies: A number of politicians with ties to Trump’s immigration agenda will also face competitive races today. They include Rep. Lou Barletta (R-Pa.), who is running for the Senate seat held by Sen. Bob Casey (D-Pa.). Another hard-liner to watch will be Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach, a Republican running in a three-way race for governor.

Eyes on Pennsylvania and Colorado: Pro-migrant group Immigration Hub circulated a midterm analysis Monday that argued Pennsylvania and Colorado will be the states to watch today. “President Trump desperately wanted to win Pennsylvania, as indicated by the eight trips he and Vice President Mike Pence made to the state,” they wrote in a brief for reporters.

UNIONS

EXCLUSIVE: AFL-CIO DROPS 3M MAILERS: Over the final three weeks in the run-up to the midterms, the AFL-CIO says it dropped some 3 million direct mail pieces targeting 24 states. The effort boosts labor-backed candidates such as Conor Lamb in Pennsylvania, Beto O’Rourke in Texas, Amy McGrath in Kentucky, among other candidates in key swing districts. “Membership polling this cycle has found that persuadable voters trust their unions more than any other source of political information,” according to the AFL-CIO.

And its effort could pay off. In Ohio, about half of union households that voted for Trump in 2016 said they’re backing Democratic Sen. Sherrod Brown and Democratic gubernatorial hopeful Richard Cordray, according to the AFL-CIO, which polled over 15,000 of its members in the state. (More on that from Vox here.)

The Communications Workers of America also say it’s running four ongoing text banks in Ohio that are focusing on Brown and Cordray. POLITICO’s analysis suggests Brown’s seat is a safe bet for Democrats. And RealClearPolitics’ polling average has Cordray up nearly 5 points.

Meanwhile, the Culinary Workers Union in Las Vegas has registered 10,300 new voters since the last election, the Huffington Post reports. It's also "helped more than 650 immigrants in Nevada become citizens this year alone." More on that here.

CORPORATE CIVICS CLASS: Corporate giants including Walmart, Tyson Foods, Levi Strauss and hundreds of other companies are offering paid time off so their employees can make it to the ballot box today, Jennifer Saba reports for The New York Times.

“A jumble of state laws and the lack of a national holiday will make voting a challenge for many workers,” Saba writes, because federal law sets Election Day on the first Tuesday of November for national elections, smack dab in the middle of the workweek. “More than 370 companies have signed on to the Make Time to Vote initiative,” Saba reports. “They are easing the path in various ways, including giving employees paid time off to vote on Nov. 6.” More here.

DACA TO SCOTUS: The Justice Department on Monday petitioned the Supreme Court to intervene in several cases over the termination of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, POLITICO’s Ted Hesson reports.

The request comes as Trump has been hurling weeks of fiery anti-immigration rhetoric in a bid to reach GOP voters, for whom immigration is a top concern. DOJ asked that the Supreme Court review three federal judges’ rulings blocking Trump’s plan to end the program, which grants work permits for and prevents the deportation of roughly 700,000 undocumented immigrants brought to the U.S. as children. More here.

TRUMP CAMPAIGN AD PULLED: NBC, Fox and Facebook all said Monday they would no longer play an ad from Trump's reelection campaign that ties Central American migrants seeking asylum to an undocumented immigrant who was convicted of killing two Sacramento sheriff's deputies in 2014, POLITICO’s Matthew Choi reports.

"After further review we recognize the insensitive nature of the ad and have decided to cease airing it across our properties as soon as possible," a NBCUniversal spokesperson said Monday. CNN had already declined to air the ad, calling it “racist.”

"We have a lot of ads,” Trump said to reporters Monday, “and they certainly are effective based on the numbers that we're seeing." Asked if the ad in question was offensive, he replied: "Well, a lot of things are offensive." More here.
