Ag’s safe haven in a Democratic House

With help from Helena Bottemiller Evich

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

IT’S ELECTION DAY: If Democrats take over the House, as many forecasters expect, the House Agriculture Committee will soon be under new (but familiar) management. So we’re taking an early look at Minnesota Democrat Collin Peterson’s record.

— MA’s 5 farm-state races to watch: Competitive contests in agricultural states and districts will likely play a decisive role in determining control of both chambers of Congress.

— The heartland’s loyalty to President Donald Trump will be put to the test. Trade turmoil, and its impact on farmers and manufacturers, might drive some voters’ decisions. The lapsed farm bill? Not so much.

— Commodity groups favored Republicans with their 2018 campaign donations this cycle. A top political finance tracker follows the money from crop processors, the sugar sector, livestock producers and other ag groups.

AG’S SAFE HAVEN IN A DEMOCRATIC HOUSE: If the chamber flips today, Collin Peterson is likely to be agriculture’s shelter from the effects of the “blue wave.” The Minnesota Democrat is widely expected to return as chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, a post he previously held from 2007 until 2011.

If the blue wave is real: Polls suggest Democrats are likely to take the House (if one trusts polls these days). If that happens, portions of the agriculture industry could end up at odds with the new majority on a range of issues, from the Waters of the U.S. rule to taxes. But under a centrist like Peterson, House Ag would be seen as a safe haven amid a more liberal caucus, reports our Helena Bottemiller Evich this morning.

“Most of agriculture views Collin Peterson as a friend,” said Andrew Walmsley, the American Farm Bureau Federation’s director of congressional relations. “If you have to work with anyone in Congress, he’s one of the better ones.”

Peterson has proven to be a centrist in nearly three decades on Capitol Hill. He’s the most conservative Democrat in the House. He’s voted more often with Trump than he ever did with former President Barack Obama. And agriculture interests are familiar with him — he’s a known commodity, unlike so many suburban and urban Democrats.

A closer fight than expected? For most of this year, Peterson’s rematch against Air Force veteran and drone pilot Dave Hughes hasn’t gotten much national attention, under the assumption that Peterson will win another term representing Minnesota’s 7th District.

Over the weekend some local reports indicated the race has tightened, but it appears Peterson still enjoys a substantial lead. Polling site FiveThirtyEight gives him a 93 percent chance of winning.

Pros, read Helena’s full story here.

5 FARM-STATE RACES TO WATCH: As MA readers know, many critical House and Senate races that will determine control of Congress for the next two years are in farm states and districts. Here are five races we’re tracking today, from the soybean belt to California’s Central Valley:

— North Dakota Senate: In this marquee race, Sen. Heidi Heitkamp faces an uphill battle against GOP Rep. Kevin Cramer. Heitkamp, widely considered the most vulnerable Democrat this cycle, has focused heavily on the plight of the state’s soybean sector and criticized Trump’s trade tactics. North Dakota soybean growers have been burned by retaliatory tariffs as badly as any group in the country.

— California House District 10: The toss-up race between Republican Rep. Jeff Denham and Democrat Josh Harder is one of several competitive contests based in the Central Valley farmlands, where the politics of agriculture, water and immigration reign.

— Mississippi (Special) Senate: There’s a four-way race to fill the seat of former Sen. Thad Cochran, and the leading Democratic candidate is former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy. The contest is likely headed to a runoff, unless one candidate clears 50 percent. Espy’s performance in the deep-red state will help measure the power of any blue wave.

— Minnesota House Districts 1 and 8: Two House Agriculture Democrats from rural Minnesota are leaving Congress, offering the GOP two of their best House pickup opportunities. Republicans Jim Hagedorn and Pete Stauber are seen as more likely than not to flip the open seats. Both districts backed Trump two years ago.

*Bonus races* to watch: Organic farmer and Democratic Sen. Jon Tester is seen as a slight favorite to win reelection in Montana. In Indiana, where GOP businessman Mike Braun is trying to unseat Democratic Sen. Joe Donnelly, Trump has made late-in-the-game visits in his effort to bolster the GOP’s chances of holding the Senate.

— “It’s really about the candidate, but if they want to give me the credit or the liability, I’ll be willing to take it,” Trump said Monday about the stakes in the Indiana race after arriving in Fort Wayne ahead of a campaign rally.

We’re also keeping tabs on toss-up governor’s races in states with major ag interests: Georgia, Iowa, Kansas, South Dakota and Wisconsin.

For more: Pro DataPoint has all the races to watch today in farm states and beyond. Want to add DataPoint to your Pro account? Learn more.

POLITICO Pro DataPoint

TRADE FALLOUT PUT TO THE TEST: There’s been no shortage of headlines and speculation about political repercussions from the trade war and its effects on farmers and manufacturers. In each of the races we highlighted above (and plenty of others), voters will finally make clear that they are truly sticking with the president — or punishing him for their trade woes.

— Widespread impact: Trump’s steel and aluminum duties and other nations’ retaliatory tariffs have dented commodity prices and driven up farm costs like chemicals and equipment.

— But, but, but: There are few indicators that the trade turmoil will drive Trump voters away from the GOP and into the Democratic column.

What’s that? The farm bill lapsed? Despite all the talk from House and Senate leaders this year about the importance of finishing a new farm bill by Oct. 1, their failure to pass a final measure before the 2014 law expired seems to have barely registered in farm-state midterm races.

— The farm bill expiration did crop up in a handful of House races in Iowa, Illinois and elsewhere, but it’s been totally overshadowed by the trade war fallout.

— The lack of campaign attention on the farm bill is also because farmers and ranchers mostly won’t notice the effects of the 2014 measure’s expiration until after December — and because there’s some expectation (or hope) that a final agreement might come together by then.

** A message from AGree: The time is now to fully fund the Farm Bill conservation title and to pass the improved agricultural data management and analysis policies included in the Senate-passed Farm Bill. These policies will unlock solutions to conserve natural resources and reduce risk and improve profitability. Learn more here. **

AG INDUSTRY 2018 DONATIONS FAVOR GOP: Pro Ag’s Liz Crampton reported Monday that farm bureaus in the top 10 ag states were spreading their campaign contributions between both parties — though the GOP received more. The nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks campaign finance and lobbying, also dug into 2018 spending by agricultural groups and found that crop producers and processors were the biggest donors among ag sectors this election cycle. And Republicans, again, were favored.

“GOP donor support is high in part because major farming operations generally contribute to incumbent politicians in the agriculturally rich districts they are located in, which are represented mostly by Republicans,” CRP wrote in its analysis of the spending data.

— Crop workers and PACs gave $14.5 million to Republicans this cycle and about $7 million to Democrats. The livestock sector donated $4.3 million to GOP candidates and $1.9 million to Democrats.

— Sugar cane and sugar beet groups came closest to sharing donations evenly between the two parties. They gave more than $3.4 million to the GOP and $2.8 million to Democrats.

— Dairy, tobacco, poultry and egg groups gave the least amount in political contributions. They each poured about $2 million to $3 million into campaigns ahead of today’s elections, mostly for Republicans.

ROW CROPS

— Advisory panel muted on NAFTA 2.0 ag impact: A U.S. advisory committee reviewing the new North American trade pact had little to say about how the deal will affect agriculture. The committee expressed concern about a provision allowing protein powders to be used for animal feed at below market prices. Pro Canada’s Alexander Panetta has more.

— Retaliatory tariffs dent pork exports to Mexico: The value of U.S. pork exports to Mexico dropped to $1 billion from January through September — down 8 percent from the same period in 2017, according to USDA data compiled by the U.S. Meat Export Federation. European and Canadian pork producers are filling the gap, Pro Trade’s Sabrina Rodriguez reports.

— More trade war fallout for soybean growers: Kevin Karel, who operates six grain elevators in North Dakota, is piling one million soybean bushels on open ground behind his jam-packed grain silos. Like soybean farmers and exporters across the U.S., he’s hoping the trade war ends soon, sales to China resume and soybean prices rise — before the stockpiled crop rots. The New York Times has the dispatch from Arthur, N.D.

— Trump says he’ll ‘take a look’ at Zinke accusations: The president offered scant support Monday for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, who is under scrutiny for ethical and potentially legal lapses. “Certainly, I would not be happy with that at all,” Trump said, referring to the possible outcome of reported government probes into Zinke’s actions as Interior chief, POLITICO’s Eliana Johnson and Pro Energy’s Zack Colman and Ben Lefebvre report.

— Crunching the cranberry glut: The cranberry industry has agreed to destroy a quarter of the 2018 crop, hoping to counteract its surplus and boost prices. (Much of last year’s crop is already sitting in storage.) About 240 million pounds will be obliterated this year, The New Food Economy writes.

— Perdue Farms building Baltimore organic grain site: The Maryland-based agribusiness will spend $30 million to open an organic grain storage and processing facility. Perdue CEO Randy Day said the company needs new access to organic grains in order to produce more organic chicken.

— Bayer CEO: Glyphosate settlements possible: Depending on costs, the agribusiness might consider settling lawsuits over the use of glyphosate in weedkillers made by Monsanto, now owned by Bayer, said chief executive Werner Baumann. Reuters has more.

— The Senate’s main function: More than 55 percent of Senate roll call votes are on nominations, a massive increase since 10 years ago, according to a Washington Post analysis. Don’t tell that to Stephen Vaden, whose nomination for Agriculture Department general counsel has stalled for nearly one year since being advanced by the Senate Ag Committee in December 2017.

WELCOME TO ELECTION DAY — WHAT’S AT STAKE FOR EDUCATION: A contentious midterm election season that was largely fought on hot-button issues of immigration, the economy and health care comes to an end today as voters head to the polls. While education may have played a minor role in most races, the results tonight could have major implications for education policy in the coming year.

We previewed on Monday some of the potential midterm election fallout for K-12 education issues and federal education funding. Higher education could also see big changes. Here’s what to watch on that front as results start rolling in:

— The balance of power in Congress: All eyes will be on which party controls the House and Senate for the 116th Congress. Democrats have promised, broadly, to exercise sweeping oversight of the Trump administration if they win committee gavels and subpoena powers in the majority — and Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and the Trump administration’s higher education moves are widely seen as prime targets.

— Democrats have cried foul over what they argue is an Education Department that’s captive to the interests of for-profit education and student loan companies. If they win the majority in either chamber, Democrats will be able to add some teeth to the scathing letters they’ve frequently sent DeVos over those issues during the past two years. Expect a Democrat-led House, for instance, to conduct hearings, demand documents and press the Trump administration on its appointment of officials with ties to for-profit colleges — and its reversal of Obama-era policies meant to crack down on the industry.

— Flying under the radar: Democrats also have in their corner a slew of new left-leaning watchdog groups that have cropped up only since the last election — and that have already been working to put the Education Department on the defensive. Groups like American Oversight, National Student Legal Defense Network and Democracy Forward have all filed multiple lawsuits against the department — many focusing on its ties to the for-profit education industry — that could prove to be a useful roadmap for newly empowered Democratic staff. In addition, Democratic attorneys general and consumer groups have forged a more aggressive and cohesive coalition that works on higher education issues since Democrats last controlled the House. They’ve challenged nearly every major DeVos policy move on higher education.

— Conversely, if Republicans maintain their grip on Congress, it could allow an emboldened Trump administration to forge ahead more smoothly on its ambitious plans to deregulate higher education and scale back federal requirements that it views as impediments to innovation. The White House has also signaled privately to some groups that it may take on a more prominent role in higher education policies in the coming months.

— At the state level, widespread Democratic wins could also spell more scrutiny for student loan companies in some states. Critics of student loan servicers are gearing up to try to convince more states to pass tighter regulations on the industry in the coming legislative sessions. Those efforts would play out amid the ongoing dispute between some states and the Trump administration over who has the authority to police companies collecting federal student loans.

STUDENT LOANS

NAVIENT SUES TRUMP ADMINISTRATION: Navient is mounting a legal challenge to the Trump administration's plans to overhaul how the federal government collects student loans. The company alleges in a lawsuit, which became public on Monday, that the Education Department's process for selecting companies for its new loan servicing platform has been unfair and violated federal procurement rules.

— Navient is one of the department's largest existing loan servicers, but it wasn't among the more than a dozen companies that the Trump administration named last month as finalists to receive contracts under its new loan servicing system. The company has said it’s still in the running as a potential subcontractor.

— The lawsuit accuses the department of "radically changing" the scope of the project in the middle of the bidding process, which it says put Navient at a competitive disadvantage. The company said it "suffered irreparable injury by the loss of the opportunity to compete on a level playing field."

— It’s the latest challenge to DeVos’ plan to overhaul and “modernize” how the federal government collects student loans. Two other existing federal loan servicers — FedLoan Servicing, which is operated by the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Authority, and the Missouri Higher Education Loan Authority — filed separate protests with GAO last week. Read more.

HIGHER EDUCATION

JUDGE TOSSES FOR-PROFIT COLLEGE’S BID TO RESTRUCTURE OUTSIDE BANKRUPTCY: A federal judge on Monday rejected an effort by a financially struggling for-profit college chain to effectively restructure itself and change ownership without first declaring bankruptcy or jumping through state and federal regulatory hurdles. Education Corporation of America, which operates Virginia College and Brightwood College, had asked a federal judge in Alabama to appoint a receiver to oversee its restructuring while also shielding the company from creditors and requiring the Education Department to continue to provide student aid funding to its schools.

— Federal law permanently bars any company that files for bankruptcy protection from ever receiving federal student aid funding. ECA argued that it needed the court’s help to make sure it would continue accessing federal student aid while it attempts to restructure itself.

— But the judge sided with the Education Department and DeVos, who were named as defendants in the company’s lawsuits and sought to dismiss the case. U.S. District Judge Abdul K. Kallon ruled that the for-profit college chain did not have standing to bring the case because it wasn’t alleging an actual or immediate injury. He didn’t rule on the merits of its case.

— The lawsuit, which describes the company’s financial situation as dire, has also triggered a sanction from its accreditor. The Accrediting Council on Independent Colleges and Schools said last week that the company must demonstrate why it shouldn’t remove approval for its Virginia College chain in light of its financial instability.

MOVERS AND SHAKERS

— Henry Duvall, director of communications at the Council of the Great City Schools for the past 26 years, will retire in January.

— Beth Stein, who previously was general counsel and chief oversight counsel for Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.) at the Senate HELP Committee, is now vice president overseeing federal policy at The Institute for College Access & Success. Patricia Balana, who previously was chief operating officer at Jobs for the Future, is now chief operating officer and chief financial officer at TICAS. The organization also added three new members to its board of directors: Frank Chong, the president of Santa Rosa Junior College; Zakiya Smith Ellis, the secretary of higher education for New Jersey; and Kate Tromble, the pastoral associate for social justice at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church.

— Patrick Dobard, CEO of New Schools for New Orleans, has been elected to the board of directors for the National Association of Charter School Authorizers.

Former Hillary Clinton adviser Philippe Reines said President Donald Trump will remain impervious to political convention or punditry. “He is a freak of nature and it doesn’t matter if he’s dumb or not. It doesn’t matter what I think. He is a bulldozer.” | Carolyn Kaster/AP photo elections Clinton aide Philippe Reines predicts Trump will win a second term

A top adviser to former presidential nominee Hillary Clinton said this week he’s not confident anyone in the 2020 Democratic field has a shot at blocking President Donald Trump from a second term.

During an interview for National Review reporter Jamie Weinstein’s podcast, Philippe Reines said that at this point he would bet on Trump being reelected in 2020.

Story Continued Below

He offered a back-handed compliment to the president, saying that Trump will remain impervious to political convention or punditry. “He is a freak of nature, and it doesn’t matter if he’s dumb or not. It doesn’t matter what I think. He is a bulldozer,” Reines said.

Reines said he thinks Trump would beat out what is sure to be a large field of Democrats “for a lot of reasons. Also because moments in history like this tend to not get resolved.”

“The only two presidents in the last 85 years that have been denied a second term: Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush. And both because they had, as a sign of trouble, they had serious primary challengers,” he continued.

COUNTDOWN TO 2020 The race for 2020 starts now. Stay in the know. Follow our presidential election coverage. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Asked which Democrat he thinks has the best shot at beating their party's opponents in a primary as well as the president, Reines responded: “I don’t know.”

"I think there are people out there who would make great presidents; I just don't know how you would get through both" the Democratic primary and the general election, he said, adding that the two are a "different dynamic" of campaign.

“I always think of it this way, that if the election were held tomorrow, stick in a name, would Trump win,” Reines said, throwing in the names of a few celebrities. “I have a hard time thinking of ... I think Tom Hanks would win, I think The Rock would win. I have a hard time seeing how a lot of the people who are running would win. Just as comparison.”

Reines, however, argued to POLITICO last month that his former boss should not be completely written off as a viable 2020 candidate, adding that there’s a “not zero” chance of Clinton making a third run at the White House. He later told The Hill that Clinton was “more likely to win the Powerball” than run again.

ELECTION DAY DRAMAS -- BROWN's final campaign swing -- COX, NEWSOM close out campaigns -- O.C. 'Reagan County' RACES down to the wire -- TECH pushes back on H1-B visa policies -- KAMALA RISING in 2020 polls Presented by California Resources Corporation

THE BUZZ: Whether or not California propels a blue wave election on Tuesday, Monday night marked a certain sea change in state politics: Jerry Brown's final campaign event as governor.

-- Appearing on a stage with Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom for the first time since June, Brown encouraged voters at an election-eve gathering in San Francisco to lift Newsom into the office Brown is preparing to vacate at the end of four terms spanning the better part of four decades. Sen. Kamala Harris was also on hand, capping a final statewide swing with Newsom that marshaled their joint clout on behalf of Democrats up and down the state.

Story Continued Below

-- True to form, Brown opened with a history lesson, noting that a Newsom victory would be the first Democrat-to-Democrat handoff of California governors in more than a century. A recurring rule of politics is that “people get a little tired of you,” Brown mused, but “luckily we’re going from the oldest governor to one that’s pretty young,” which he said would “freshen up the process.”

-- “Things are really screwed up” in the world, Brown, 80, said. He noted the global authoritarian lurch of governments from Hungary to the Philippines to Brazil — but also said, “If you look at some of our red states — craaazy.” But while President Donald Trump governs by wielding fear, Brown said, “Gavin’s about vision, boldness and getting stuff done,” praising him as “energetic” and “visionary.” His reference to a future Newsom presidential run got the most sustained applause of the night — but Brown still worked in a wink.

-- QUOTE OF THE DAY: “I’ll be watching from the ranch,” Brown noted, but “I’m only an hour from Sacramento, so Gavin, do not screw up.”

FIVE TO WATCH ON TUESDAY:

1. REAGAN COUNTRY RACES: Ronald Reagan once called Orange County, the storied conservative bastion, “the place good Republicans go to die.” And this year, with demographic shifts and the effects of a controversial presidency, it could happen, politically speaking. The majority of those famed seven targeted House races in districts held by RepublIcans and won in 2016 by Hillary Clinton are in the O.C. Rep. Dana Rohrabacher of Huntington Beach is in the fight for his life against Democrat Harley Rouda in CA-48. Rep. Mimi Walters of Irvine has faced a beat-down from UC Irvine law professor and consumer advocate Katie Porter in CA-45. Democrats are considered likely to pick up CA-49, where Democrat Mike Levin leads Republican Diane Harkey in the race to succeed retiring Rep. Darrell Issa. The race in CA-39, where Rep. Ed Royce is retiring, is closer, with Republican Young Kim and. Democrat Gil Cisneros running neck-and-neck. Farther north of LA, don’t forget CA-25’s nail-biter between Rep. Steve Knight, challenged by Dem Katie Hill . Control of the House runs through the O.C.; all eyes will be here Tuesday night.

2. ROADS AND HOMES: There’s plenty to analyze on a crowded ballot initiative slate, but Propositions 6 and 10 stand out as big-money political signposts. In seeking to repeal a 12-cents-a-gallon gas tax, Prop. 6 directly tests the supremacy of two opposing political forces: on one side the state’s Democratic-dominated government, with legislative Democrats using two-thirds majorities to send Brown a legacy accomplishment that he’s spent his final campaign cycle defending; and on the other the state’s shriveled Republican electorate, which GOP officials hope to galvanize with an anti-tax revolt. And Prop. 10 reflects the ubiquity of a housing affordability crisis that dominates California politics. It also tests the strength of an ascendant build-baby-build emphasis that’s been embraced by Newsom, who’s defied much of the liberal base by opposing Prop. 10 and saying it would chill development.

3. STEVE POIZNER AND “THE RISE OF THE INDEPENDENTS”: If Steve Poizner grabs the brass ring to become California’s state insurance commissioner, he could signal a new trend heading toward 2020. Poizner, the former GOP gubernatorial candidate who has since abandoned the party, won 24 of 24 statewide newspaper endorsements in this bid, shellacking Democratic state Sen. Ricardo Lara on that front. If he manages to jump the hurdle of Democrats’ 19-point registration advantage over the GOP, Poizner will be seen as a harbinger for more moderate Republicans who want a path to victory away from Trump in 2020. And then watch Poizner, a wealthy tech executive, become subject of buzz about what office he might seek next.

4. A BLUE TSUNAMI? HERE'S THE KEY: Look to the fate of GOP Reps. Duncan Hunter and Devin Nunes, who have previously coasted to reelection in two of the state’s most loyal GOP districts. But CA-50’s Hunter, indicted on 60 counts related to fraud and campaign finance violations, met a surprisingly strong challenge from Democrat Ammar Campa-Najjar, and responded with ads condemned as anti-Muslim. ( Here’s the LATimes rundown. ) And CA-22’s Nunes was relentlessly targeted by Fresno prosecutor Andrew Janz, (here’s RealClearPolitics’ take ) who turned out big crowds, raised millions of dollars and hit thousands of homes in an effort to unseat the chair of the House Intelligence Committee. If both challengers succeed, then Republicans nationwide probably already know they're deep, deep trouble.

5. THE STEYER EFFECT: The billionaire California Democratic activist has roamed the country this year, hammering home his message and collecting 6 million signatures for his NeedtoImpeach.com. But a main goal: focusing heavily on younger voters, who failed to turn out in the 2016 election. As The Guardian reported Monday , "37% of young Americans in six key states say they will definitely vote or have already voted. In the 2014 midterms, only 23% voted,’’ according to data provided by the group. 2020 watchers will be watching Steyer’s win record Tuesday.

Expect to see: the former San Francisco mayor, current Mayor London Breed, “scores of politicos, current & past office holders, Bay Area and California candidates for election, campaign workers, celebrities, tech billionaires -- and hundreds of San Franciscans who never pass up a free lunch.”

TRAIL MIX

JOHN COX's LAST STAND IN LIBERAL-LAND: Berkeley may be the type of liberal bastion where an avowed Democratic socialist is in a heated race against an Obama-endorsed Democrat, but it also shares the Bay Area’s crippling housing costs, a dynamic that Republican gubernatorial candidate John Cox emphasized as he spent the morning before the election at an auto repair shop in a city he called “one of the major centers” of the affordability crisis.

-- FOUR VOTERS, 24 CAMERAS: Sitting in front of crumpled car frames, employees shared stories of lengthy commutes — some from as far as Modesto and Manteca — which Cox called collateral damage of prohibitive housing costs. He vowed, if elected, to streamline regulations and immediately convene a special session on housing. “I just live out here because I love the weather,'' said Cox, noting how much cheaper it is to build housing in Indiana, where he owns properties, than in California.

Sean Hannity’s close relationship with President Donald Trump has put him under the microscope of media watchers who have accused Fox News of being too friendly with the White House. | Carolyn Kaster/AP photo media Fox News raps Hannity for appearing onstage at Trump rally The Fox News host said he was unaware he would be invited on stage, but the White House had billed him as a "special guest."

Fox News censured its biggest star Tuesday, saying that Sean Hannity should not have appeared onstage a night earlier with President Donald Trump at his final campaign rally before the midterm elections.

Hannity’s cameo appearance Monday in Cape Girardeau, Missouri, directly contradicted a pledge he had made hours earlier not to take the stage with the president. It also contradicted assurances from network brass that, despite a Trump campaign press release touting Hannity’s appearance as part of the rally, he would not be a guest of the president's.

Story Continued Below

The incident revealed a network struggling to reign in its biggest star, who has flaunted the independence that comes with sky-high ratings and privileged status inside Fox News. Fellow host Jeanine Pirro also appeared on stage with the president Monday.

“FOX News does not condone any talent participating in campaign events,” a Fox News spokesperson said in a statement. “We have an extraordinary team of journalists helming our coverage tonight and we are extremely proud of their work. This was an unfortunate distraction and has been addressed.”

It was not immediately clear how Fox News addressed the incident with its hosts.

While Hannity has traveled to Trump rallies plenty of times to host his show on-site and interview the president, questions about his role at the Missouri rally stemmed from the White House. In an email sent out before the rally, the White House billed Hannity as a “special guest” along with conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh and musician Lee Greenwood.

Playbook PM Sign up for our must-read newsletter on what's driving the afternoon in Washington. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Hannity replied on Twitter that “I will be doing a live show from Cape Girardeau and interviewing President Trump before the rally. To be clear, I will not be on stage campaigning with the President. I am covering [the] final rally for my show. Something I have done in every election in the past.”

Nonetheless, after interviewing Trump live for his show, Hannity was called onstage by the president, to raucous applause. The host promptly pointed to the media members assembled in the back of the room — which included Fox News staff — labeling them “fake news.”

Hannity said in his comments that he had been unaware he would be invited onstage, but he spoke briefly about the president’s accomplishments and repeated Trump’s 2020 reelection slogan, “Promises made, promises kept.”

Pirro, whose show the president has regularly praised, was also called by Trump up to the stage, where she urged the crowd to vote for Republicans.

Hannity claimed on Twitter Tuesday that he had not misrepresented his plans: “What I said in my tweet yesterday was 100% truthful. When the POTUS invited me on stage to give a few remarks last night, I was surprised, yet honored by the president’s request. This was NOT planned."

What I said in my tweet yesterday was 100% truthful. When the POTUS invited me on stage to give a few remarks last night, I was surprised, yet honored by the president’s request. This was NOT planned. — Sean Hannity (@seanhannity) November 6, 2018

He also sought to do clean-up on his "fake news" crack.

"To be clear, I was not referring to my journalist colleagues at FOX News in those remarks," Hannity wrote. "They do amazing work day in and day out in a fair and balanced way and it is an honor to work with such great professionals.”

But Hannity’s performance Monday night upset some current and former Fox News employees, particularly because he didn't exempt his coworkers from his shot at the media. Reporter Kristin Fisher was covering the rally for the network.

“I think it was the fake news swipe that teed off a lot of people," said one former Fox News employee, saying that by Tuesday morning, five former colleagues who are still at the network had been in touch about the incident. “The shot at the media, he does that every night on his show. There’s nothing new about that. What does change it is his colleagues were back there.”

Fox News often labors to distinguish between its opinion hosts, who almost universally support Trump, and its news division, which the network says works as objectively as any other.

But another former Fox News employee, who worked in the company’s news division, said this type of incident makes reporters' jobs more difficult because it makes the network seem too close to the White House.

During Fox News’ 11 p.m. newscast, when anchor Shannon Bream went to Fisher to report on the rally, Fisher cited Hannity’s interview with Trump but did not mention his comments on stage.

Trump’s relationship with Fox News has long been tight and has only grown more snug throughout his presidency. Hannity is known to be one of Trump’s top advisers, speaking with the president frequently. And there has been a highway between the network and the White House, with officials such as White House communications chief Bill Shine, top State Department spokesperson Heather Nauert and national security adviser John Bolton all having previously worked at the network. Nauert is viewed as a leading contender to replace Nikki Haley as UN ambassador.

Trump’s interview with Hannity on Monday night marked his 38th on the network’s air since taking office, far more than any other network, according to a POLITICO count. In second place is CBS News, with four Trump interviews. Trump also frequently tweets about shows on the network, sometimes appearing to tweet commentary in real time, and on Monday, he told Hannity that he never misses the primetime show’s opening monologue.

Hannity’s friendship with Trump had previously gotten him in trouble with his employer for pushing the limits of his role as an opinion commentator. He was reprimanded by Fox in 2016 after he appeared in a campaign video endorsing Trump.

In 2010, the Fox host arranged to broadcast his show as part of a Tea Party rally in Cincinnati, with proceeds of his appearance to go to the local Tea Party group. Fox News executives, who had been caught unaware by Hannity’s plans, barred him from appearing and called the host back to New York.

A Los Angeles Times story at the time quoted Shine, then the network’s executive vice president of programming, as saying, “Fox News never agreed to allow the Cincinnati Tea Party organizers to use Sean Hannity’s television program to profit from broadcasting his show from the event. When senior executives in New York were made aware of this, we changed our plans for tonight’s show.”

The incident doesn't seem to have damaged their relationship permanently. According to a pool report, after his interview with Trump Monday night, Hannity fist-bumped Shine.

WILL REPUBLICANS HOLD THE HOUSE? -- What a Dem win means for Trump -- 36M VOTE EARLY -- How Dems got free rent

By Nolan D. McCaskill ( nmccaskill@politico.com or @NolanDMcCaskill )

With an assist from Burgess Everett

Story Continued Below

CAN REPUBLICANS KEEP THEIR POWER? -- President Donald Trump appears to accept the polling and projections that indicate Democrats will win the House and Republicans will maintain or expand their Senate majority, as evidenced by the president’s Senate and gubernatorial-focused campaign sprint in the lead-up to Election Day. Apparently resigned to losing the House, Trump told reporters “I don’t care” if Democrats pursue his tax returns. “They can do whatever they want, and I can do whatever I want.”

“Working for President Donald Trump has never been easy, but his staffers can expect a whole new level of mayhem if Democrats win control of the House on Tuesday,” Andrew Restuccia and Darren Samuelsohn warn. “Democratic control of even one chamber of Congress would unleash an onslaught of hearings, subpoenas and document demands as lawmakers investigate everything from the president’s personal tax returns to his controversial policies on immigration, health care and the environment.” Veterans of past White Houses say oversight “can make daily life in the White House unbearable for senior officials and their aides,” they write. Much more: https://politi.co/2OtCQiC

Related: “What If They Blow It? Democrats Contemplate a Red Wave Abyss,” by Esquire’s Ryan Lizza: http://bit.ly/2DmFYfa ; and “A Democratic Senate May Hinge on Arizona and Nevada. Could They Flip?” from The New York Times’ Lisa Lerer and Jose A. Del Real: https://nyti.ms/2DqRer7

EARLY VOTE NUMBERS -- More than 36 million ballots have already been cast, setting the stage for an unusually high turnout for a midterm year. “The high voting rates have transformed expectations about who will show up in the midterms -- and they could inspire results that diverge from any pre-election polls that did not reckon with this year’s unusually high enthusiasm,” Zach Montellaro reports. “Analysts cautioned against drawing broad conclusions about which party could gain an advantage from the high early vote totals. But they did note that pre-election polls make built-in assumptions about how many people will vote, and pollsters who leaned too heavily on past midterm turnout may have misfired.” Much more: https://politi.co/2RyqXKi

Related read: “Am I Registered to Vote? Answers to Common Questions on Election Day,” via The New York Times’ Julia Jacobs: https://nyti.ms/2D3BZTX

NO EVIDENCE, NO PROBLEM -- The president floated his own evidence-free claim that voter fraud may threaten the results of the midterm elections, tweeting that law enforcement will “closely” monitor any illegal voting. Attorney General Jeff Sessions also announced that DOJ’s Civil Rights Division will look out for compliance with federal voting rights laws by dispatching officials to jurisdictions in 19 states. Fraud, Sessions said, “corrupts the integrity of the ballot” and “will not be tolerated.” Trump told reporters that, based on his opinion and “proof,” a lot of people succeed in voting illegally.

Reality check: “There is no evidence of widespread voter fraud in the United States,” The Washington Post’s Amy Gardner writes. “Trump formed a commission to study the issue shortly after he took office that was disbanded without finding evidence of fraud after states refused to turn over voter data. Voting rights advocates denounced Trump’s remarks as a blatant attempt to intimidate voters on the eve of Election Day -- and part of a pattern among Republicans, they said, to curtail voting access with strict rules that disproportionately affect voters of color who tend to vote Democratic.” More: https://wapo.st/2ySe1b9

Related: “10 places where the 2018 midterms will be won and lost,” by Charlie Mahtesian: https://politi.co/2PFrw82

LUJÁN EYES RUN FOR ASSISTANT DEM LEADER -- DCCC Chairman Ben Ray Luján (D-N.M.) is preparing to run for assistant Democratic leader, with the assumption that Democrats win the House and the top three leaders become speaker, majority leader and majority whip. Reps. Cheri Bustos (D-Ill.) and David Cicilline (D-R.I.) have already announced their candidacies. “A Democratic chief of staff said Luján would be the favorite in that contest since Democrats would be eager to reward the New Mexico lawmaker if he shepherds the party to victory on Tuesday,” The Hill’s Scott Wong and Mike Lillis write. “But a Luján run could complicate the race, because many members have committed their support to Bustos or Cicilline.” More: http://bit.ly/2Ryovn4

Related: “How Democrats Got to the Precipice of a House Majority,” by National Journal’s Ally Mutnick: http://bit.ly/2D5GKMK ; and “‘I know the ropes’: Pelosi makes her case for leader as Democrats chase House majority,“ from The Washington Post’s Mike DeBonis: https://wapo.st/2F71NRB

MURPHY’S HALF MILLION: Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) has been feeling good enough about his own reelection campaign to direct $500,000 to the DSCC to help his endangered colleagues. Murphy has transferred $180,000 from his Friends of Chris Murphy and raised $320,000 to the DSCC through donors and events. Perhaps not so coincidentally, he’s been one of the most bullish Democrats on picking up seats tonight.

GRAHAM SIGNALS SESSIONS’ RESIGNATION -- Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) told conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt that Attorney General Jeff Sessions will “probably” resign and predicted a new nominee will be confirmed “most likely early next year.” Graham could oversee the process for replacing Sessions if Senate Republicans keep their majority and Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) chairs the Senate Finance Committee, opening the door for Graham to lead the judiciary panel. “Graham, whose fiery, nationally televised defense of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh amid accusations of sexual misconduct drew widespread attention, said that Democrats’ ‘complete destruction’ of Kavanaugh during his confirmation process would begin a new chapter for the Judiciary Committee,” Caitlin Oprysko writes. More: https://politi.co/2JHoMBu

Related read: “Trump prepares to remake his Cabinet,” per CNN’s Jeff Zeleny, Kevin Liptak, Laura Jarrett and Barbara Starr: https://cnn.it/2JIoTNb

LAW AND DISORDER -- Gone are the days when Congress compromised on the day’s biggest issues and exercised its authority to declare war, spend taxpayer funds and provide a check on the presidency. “It has been replaced by a weakened legislative branch in which debate is strictly curtailed, party leaders dictate the agenda, most elected representatives rarely get a say, and government shutdowns are a regular threat because of chronic failures to agree on budgets,” The Washington Post’s Paul Kane and ProPublica’s Derek Willis report based off an analysis of congressional data and documents.

Since Barack Obama was elected president, the analysis found, “the political center has largely evaporated [and] party leaders have adhered to the demands of their bases, while rules and traditions that long encouraged deliberative dealmaking have given way to partisan gridlock,” they write. “While few of these changes made headlines, taken together they have fundamentally altered the way Congress operates -- and morphed this equally powerful branch of government into one that functions more as a junior partner to the executive, or doesn’t function at all when it comes to the country’s pressing priorities.” Much more: https://wapo.st/2qxf3Vw

PROBLEM SOLVERS? -- Republican members of the bipartisan 48-person Problem Solvers Caucus have touted their involvement in the group in debates, interviews and ads. “But to some critics in both parties, the Problem Solvers offer little more than a thin veneer of bipartisanship that clouds rather than clarifies the stakes of the 2018 midterm elections -- an election-year talking point that vulnerable incumbents can tout without accomplishing much,” The Washington Post’s Jeff Stein writes. On average, the group’s GOP members have voted in line with the White House 93 percent of the time. “Everyone I talked to said, ‘This group has done almost nothing,’” said Andrew Grant, the Republican candidate challenging Rep. Ami Bera (D-Calif.). More: https://wapo.st/2AOXaYw

Related: “The Demise of the Moderate Republican,” by The New Yorker’s George Packer: http://bit.ly/2QmZCum

FREE RENT -- House Democrats have exploited campaign finance law to pay rent for dozens of candidates’ campaign offices this year. According to FEC records, some Democrats have paid zero rent for their campaign headquarters, while others who rented space this year abruptly stopped some or all of their payments after their primaries. The DCCC has picked up the tab, spending more than $1 million in rent in 22 states this cycle. “The spending … comes from a special fund established under a 2014 law that the DCCC can use only to maintain party headquarters buildings -- not for other conventional campaign activities,” Scott Bland reports. House Republicans, who don’t have a similar program, are crying foul. More: https://politi.co/2F5oWUu

11 BIG QUESTIONS — PRITZKER’s statewide plan — WILSON: Build casino, legalize marijuana

Happy Election DAY, Illinois! POLITICO will have the latest results with updating House and Senate maps throughout the night, as well as live analysis — I’ll be on from 6 to 6:30 p.m. taking your questions and talking about the biggest races.

THE BUZZ

11 questions for the day:

Story Continued Below

1. What are the most important races to watch? All the congressional contests, of course, because their outcomes could determine whether Democrats gain control of the U.S. House of Representatives. Specifically, watch the 6th and 14th Districts. Incumbent Rep. Randy Hultgren (14th) is in a race for his life against Democrat Lauren Underwood. Hultgren is a low-key Republican who’s run a low-key race. Maybe it worked in years’ past but this time he faces an energetic woman in an election year when women are posting historic gains. Underwood has out-raised and out-spent Hultgren and it shows in the polls.

Similarly, Rep. Peter Roskam is in a battle with Dem challenger Sean Casten in the 6th District, which Hillary Clinton won by seven points in 2016.

2. What’s the outlook for the governor’s race? Internal polls have shown Democratic challenger J.B. Pritzker with a double-digit lead over Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner. But after 2016, no one wants to get too confident with polls. Rauner dismisses them.

3. How will the governor’s race affect the outcome of GOP races? The Republican governor has been a definite lag on all the GOP races, according to D and R sources. “If he loses by 10 or more, it’s going to be a tough day for Republicans,” predicted one GOP operative. Rauner’s failure to invest big in candidates or in the party has resulted in “under-funded Republican campaigns versus over-funded Dem campaigns.” The irony is that four years ago he did exactly what Pritzker’s done this time around. Watch for the outcomes of three open state house seats now held by Republicans Steve Andersson of Geneva, Mike Fortner of West Chicago and David Harris of Mount Prospect.

4. When will we know the outcome of the governor’s race? If the margin is as wide as some polls suggest, it could be an early call.

5. If Pritzker wins, what will he do first? Expect big, sweeping announcements in the coming days--including a plan for statewide broadband internet.

6. Why is the attorney general’s race so close? Lots of reasons, according to observers in in D and R camps. Republican Erika Harold is within striking distance of Democratic state Sen. Kwame Raoul, who has an edge in polls. Harold has called attention to the fact that she could be the only Republican in statewide public office, allowing for a check on the Democrat leadership. That argument hits home with voters. The only person more unpopular than Donald Trump in Illinois these days, seems to be House Speaker Mike Madigan. Harold also is poised and polished. Raoul, meanwhile, “is smart and a good legislator but not a natural campaigner or debater,” as one Democrat put it. Big question if Harold loses: Should she have gone on TV sooner?

7. Where would we see early signs of a blue wave? Watch for results from races in the western suburbs, northwest suburbs and Lake County. The 6th and 14th congressional districts mentioned above could signal a blue wave that helps carry Democrats to control the U.S. House. A few statehouse races also will be affected. In District 54, for example, the outcome of the race between Republican state Rep. Tom Morrison and Democratic challenger Maggie Trevor will indicate what GOP voters have the stomach for. Morrison drew headlines for writing a letter vouching for a convicted child abuser in Arizona—someone he knew from his teaching days in Arlington Heights. Morrison retracted the letter, but it’s raised questions about his judgment. Will suburban Republicans overlook that? Another race to watch is state Rep. Peter Breen’s against Democrat Terra Costa Howard in the 48th District. Breen’s “extreme positions” were in the spotlight with Trump abortion and the Supreme Court hearings, according to a Dem operative. Breen became a target for Personal PAC, a pro-choice political action committee.

8. Is there a Trump effect in Illinois? Absolutely. Look for it to play out in a variety of ways. The president probably helped in a few races in central and southern Illinois, including Republican incumbents Mike Bost (12th) and Rodney Davis (13th). Bost faces Democrat Brendan Kelly, the state's attorney of St. Clair County. And Davis faces Dem challenger Betsy Dirksen Londrigan. The races are among the closest in the country. Should Bost and/or Davis win, they can credit Trump for getting them over the line with the GOP base. Farther north, Hultgren’s district supported Trump, so no surprise the Republican zipped downstate to hang with the president when he visited here the other day. But for Roskam, Trump is kryptonite. Trump could also impact the Cook County 17th District commissioner race between first-time Dem candidate Abdelnasser Rashid and incumbent Sean Morrison, who’s also chair of the Cook County Republican Party. Some polls have had the race deadlocked. The district stretching from Des Plaines to Orland Park is considered Republican. Democrats also have targeted Tim Schneider, the Republicans state party chairman.

9. What about the 3rd District congressional race between neo-Nazi Republican Arthur Jones and Democrat Rep. Dan Lipinski? Watch to see if write-in candidate Justin Hanson makes any headway. He’s been on a mission to inform constituents about Jones’ past.

10. A judicial races to watch: The outcome of embattled Cook County Circuit Judge Matthew Coghlan will say something about voters—whether they read all the literature that said Coghlan shouldn’t be retained.

11. Do long lines at polls mean more voters? It’s too early to tell. The state has a record number of registered voters for this election with 8.05 million. That's higher than the 2016 presidential election (8.03 million) and well above the 2014 midterm (7.48 million). Illinois also has “vastly exceeded” the number of early votes and mail votes cast before Election Day in the 2014 midterm (1.15 million today; 791,000 in 2014), says Matt Dietrich, spokesman for the Illinois State Board of Elections. And we’re close to the 2016 pace for total early/mail count, which was 1.89 million. So what does that all mean? More people voting could transfer to a boost for Democrats, though that’s not a given. After a year of #MeToo, these midterms are expected to see more women and more young people at the polls, which also usually favors Democrats.

CAMPAIGNS

— Mayoral candidate Willie Wilson caused a stir at the City Club luncheon when he said he wants to tackle city pension problems by building a casino and legalizing marijuana. The dozens of black and Latino ministers in the room almost choked on their Maggiano’s chicken at the the very thought.

Wilson: “When I go over to Hammond, Indiana, I see a lot of you all in them casinos over there,” he said. “I think we need to legalize marijuana. That could bring in billions of dollars a year (too). I know we got ministers in here. But some of the time, I know probably you all at one time smoked it yourself, alright?” There was a burst of collective laughter. Talk about finesse.

The candidate was less subtle on other issues. If mayor, Wilson would bag red-light cameras and the 7-cent bag tax. And he’d let seniors ride the CTA for free. Wilson vowed he’d be the next mayor, but first he faces a crowd of candidates--including at least half a dozen African Americans who could pull away votes. That seems to irritate Wilson to no end. “They ain’t got no money,” said the self-made millionaire. “They need to get out of the way.”

Once upon a time in New York, a reporter asked a party hack if he thought reformers would win an upcoming mayoral election. The hack was astonished. No chance, he said. The reformers, he explained, didn’t have anybody watching the polls. They didn’t know if their voters were turning out.

Political professionals know that righteousness doesn’t win elections. Neither does a great series of position papers. And even charisma isn’t enough if you don’t get out the vote. More than a century ago, an ambitious Democratic district leader from Manhattan’s old Gashouse District — where Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village are now — had his people watching polls and reporting back who had voted, and who had not, by 3 p.m. The leader dispatched handwritten notes to those missing in action, reminding them of their civic duty. A few years later, the district leader, Charles Francis Murphy, became the boss of Tammany Hall. And everybody knew why: He could get out the vote.

On days like today, it’s not about what you’ve promised and not even about what you’ve delivered. It’s not about who you’ve scared or who you’ve inspired. It’s all about getting your people to exercise their franchise. The best among the political class try to make that process easy. The worst scheme to make it hard.

The late Mario Biaggi exhibited the best and the worst of politics. The grandfather of Alessandra Biaggi, who is expected to clinch a Senate seat tonight as part of this year’s progressive wave in New York, ended his long congressional career in 1988 in disgrace. But long before he was found guilty of corruption charges, Biaggi carried on a years-long personal crusade to move Election Day to Sunday, rather than the traditional Tuesday. He was convinced that Sunday voting would bring more people to the polls, and that was a good thing. Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter all sort-of endorsed Biaggi’s idea after they left office, but needless to say, it hasn’t quite happened.

Here’s one more small Election Day mediation: There’s no question that this year’s midterms have inspired an extraordinary amount of energy and enthusiasm on both sides of the partisan divide. That’s good for democracy. And do you know who you can thank for that?

Yeah, him. — Terry Golway

13 THINGS TO WATCH ON ELECTION DAY: This year’s gubernatorial race was decided on primary night, when Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s landslide victory over Cynthia Nixon confirmed that he would indeed easily win a third term. At least that was the conventional wisdom until Sunday, when a Siena poll revealed that Republican Marc Molinaro has significantly narrowed the gap with Cuomo in recent weeks, letting the the challenger invoke the possibility of a surprise come from behind win similar to George Pataki’s in 1994. It is an unlikely scenario, for reasons discussed below, but the numbers at least leave Molinaro with the faintest glimmer of a pulse heading into Election Day. The biggest intrigue surrounds legislative contests. Democrats are optimistic that they can win a majority in the state Senate for only the fifth time since World War II and have enough members for a functioning majority for the first time since the 1930s. There might be signs that it’s a wave year favoring the left, but Democrats have notoriously found ways to miss out on easy paths to the majority in the past, so nothing will be certain until late Tuesday night. And in Congress, Democratic hopes for a majority could hinge in large part on picking up at least two of the nine House seats currently held by Republicans in the state’s suburban and upstate House districts. Here, from Bill Mahoney and me, are 13 Things to Watch today, from turnout, to the garbage plate factor, to the great gender divide. Read here.

WHAT ALBANY'S READING

LOOKS LIKE IT’S ‘AMAZON’ CUOMO — Amazon said to plan HQ2 site in Long Island City, Queens: “After conducting a yearlong search for a second home, Amazon has switched gears and is now finalizing plans to have a total of 50,000 employees in two locations, according to people familiar with the decision-making process. The company is nearing a deal to move to the Long Island City neighborhood of Queens, according to two of the people briefed on the discussions. Amazon is also close to a deal to move to the Crystal City area of Arlington, Va., a Washington suburb, one of the people said. Amazon already has more employees in those two areas than anywhere else outside of Seattle, its home base, and the Bay Area. Amazon executives met two weeks ago with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in the governor’s Manhattan office, said another of the people briefed on the process, adding that the state had offered potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in subsidies. Long Island City is a short subway ride across the East River from Midtown Manhattan.

‘I am doing everything I can,’ Governor Cuomo told reporters when asked Monday about the state’s efforts to lure the company...’I’ll change my name to Amazon Cuomo if that’s what it takes,’ Governor Cuomo said.” New York Times’s Karen Weise and J. David Goodman

LABOR RESPONDS: “"Amazon, one of the wealthiest and largest companies in history, needs the city more than the city needs Amazon – plain and simple. If Amazon wants to come here they can afford to do so on their own. RWDSU is deeply concerned about using tax payer subsidies for a company run by the richest man on earth to set up shop in our city, especially when it’s something they want to do and can do on their own anyway. Tax payers shouldn’t be on the hook to help Amazon be profitable – it’s a massively profitable private business,” said Stuart Appelbaum, President of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.

YAS QUEENS: “New York City last week announced $180 million in new spending on Long Island City to bolster transit, fix the sewer system and attract new, good-paying jobs. Now it appears that spending was, in part, deliberately timed...The arrival of Amazon in Long Island City could finally establish New York as a technology hub on par with its West Coast rivals. But some residents worry about the effects of so many newcomers on the neighborhood of gleaming apartment towers and low-rise manufacturing that is already straining from rapid growth. The neighborhood has seen a swift rise in new building that began with a single high-rise office tower, opened in 1990 and belonging to Citigroup. If the name Long Island City once seemed aspirational, in recent years it has been more descriptive: Apartment towers now dot the skyline, crowding around the elevated No. 7 subway train. There have been 41 new apartment buildings built there since 2010, according to an analysis by the city. Last year, more new apartments were built in Long Island City than in any other neighborhood in New York. The reasons, in large measure, are its proximity to Manhattan, its relatively low cost and the views…" NYT’s J. David Goodman

Cuomo at a get-out-the-vote event in Brooklyn for himself and state Senate candidate Andrew Gounardes said the fate of races up and down the ticket will come down to turnout, which he said he believes ‘is going to massive for the Democrats.’ He said New Yorkers—including moderate Republicans--will be fired up by voting for Democrats in order to send a message against what he called Trump’s message of ‘hate’ and ‘fear.’ As he has done throughout the campaign, Cuomo, seeking a third, four-year term, continued to largely ignore Molinaro.” [Daily News’ Kerry Purke and Ken Lovett]

WHAT CITY HALL IS READING

YES! YES! MAYBE? — POLITICO’s Sally Goldenberg: Candidates vying for citywide office in 2021 will have to decide whether to opt into a reformed campaign finance system or stick with the old rules, should the mayor’s ballot initiative pass on Tuesday. The ballot question, one of three born out of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s $3 million Charter Revision Commission, would cut maximum donations in New York City races from $5,100 to $2,000, while increasing the taxpayer-backed match on contributions. Proponents say it would reduce the influence of well-heeled donors by stretching smaller donations further: the city would match the first $250 of every qualifying contribution by 8-to-1. Currently, $175 of each donation gets a 6-to-1 match. As a result, they say challengers to incumbents will have a better shot at victory. “One of the things that has really worried people and alienated people about the political process is that there’s too much money in it,” de Blasio — who has benefited throughout his political career from the same kinds of donations he’s now denouncing — told parishioners at Christian Cultural Center on Sunday. “We don’t want elections to be about money; we want them to be about people,” he added. Read more here.

THE TRANSLATOR PARADOX: “New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has expanded a program that puts more translators at polling places across the city, but good government groups fear they won't be able to connect with voters. That's because the city's Board of Election is requiring them to set up more than 100 feet away. Common Cause New York is demanding the mayor's office and the city's Board of Elections get on the same page in order to serve the needs of New Yorkers. "This is a very solvable situation if you have two entities that want to serve the voters and not politically posture," said Susan Lerner, the group's executive director. A voter is allowed to bring one of the translators inside the polling place to help them cast their ballot, but according to the city, the Board of Elections is requiring the translators to adhere to electioneering laws and thus demanding that they stay away from the building's entrance. Lerner contested that interpretation and said Common Cause helped provide bipartisan training to the translators.” WNYC

BOBS — ‘Corrupt’ vs. ‘rubber stamp’: Menendez, Hugin make closing arguments, by POLITICO's Ryan Hutchins: Sen. Bob Menendez said Monday his Republican rival, Bob Hugin, would be “just another rubber stamp” for President Donald Trump and portrayed his own reelection as being as much as referendum on the president as on his own record. Hugin, a former pharmaceutical executive, continued to label Menendez a “corrupt” politician and called him “the worst senator New Jersey’s ever had,” declaring the Democrat is “not the role model for our children and our grandchildren.” Those were the closing arguments in a vicious, months-long, $50 million battle for a U.S. Senate seat few thought would be in jeopardy of falling into Republican hands, despite a failed effort to prosecute Menendez on federal corruption charges. Tom MacArthur came in second [among regional lawmakers] behind [Pennsylvania Republican Rep. Brian] Fitzpatrick, spending close to $210,000. ‘It’s not a waste of taxpayer dollars,’ said MacArthur, who considers constituent outreach to be a priority … Taxpayer-funded mail made more sense in the 1700s than it does now, said Melanie Sloan with American Oversight, a government accountability group. ‘The goals behind it are good. CARAVANS: ONE OF JAY WEBBER’S ‘KITCHEN TABLE ISSUES’ — “Migrant caravan? NJ voters are more concerned about health care and the economy,” by The Record’s Charles Stile: “As President Donald Trump talked up his plans to deploy 15,000 troops to confront a ‘national emergency’ at the Mexican border, Democratic activist Amber Pallante walked through a Burlington County neighborhood late last month, worried about the closer-to-home threat of losing health insurance. ‘I care about what there is going to be for my kids,'’ said Pallante, a canvasser for Andy Kim, the Democratic candidate for the 3rd Congressional District … Yet poll after poll in New Jersey has said that concerns over health care far outweigh worries about the economy, ethics and other issues, including immigration. In fact, health care has been a top voter priority for more than a decade, and most dramatically in 2010, with a Tea Party-fueled backlash over the Affordable Care Act, President Barack Obama's signature health care law. Right-wing critics called the Affordable Care Act socialized medicine that threatened the very fabric of democracy. They warned that ‘Obamacare’ would destroy the economy. The campaign of fury worked. Democrats lost 63 House seats and majority control that year in Obama's 2010 midterms — a ‘shellacking,’ he called it.” Read the report

Samples taken from the Pequannock Water Treatment Plant — which provides drinking water to Newark’s North, West, South and Central wards — has exceeded the federal limit of 15 parts per billion since early 2017, according to the draft obtained by POLITICO. In the first half of 2017, 5.3 percent of the samples taken exceeded 50 parts per billion. The percentage remained relatively unchanged (5.1 percent) in the second half of 2017 before falling to 2.2 percent in 2018. Read the report

WHAT TO WATCH on ELECTION DAY — Is TODAY about TRUMP? —WARREN needs to WIN BIG — BAKER’S margin

GOOD MORNING, MASSACHUSETTS. And welcome to a special Election Day edition of Massachusetts Playbook. Where are you watching the results come in tonight?

HERE’S WHAT I’M WATCHING...

— Who turns out? Secretary of State Bill Galvin expects 2.4 million Massachusetts voters will cast ballots in this year's midterm, including the 584,000 early voters. We have around 4.5 million registered voters in Massachusetts, so the expected turnout is about half of that. Stay tuned on whether turnout ends up being higher — especially among newly registered voters — like we're seeing in other states.

Story Continued Below

Baker's margin — He's America's most popular governor, he's leading in the polls and he's polling better with Democrats than his Democratic opponent. So what's Baker's winning margin going to be? "Massachusetts voters are perfectly content with moderate Republican governors and they have been forever," political analyst Peter Ubertaccio told me yesterday. But can Baker beat former Gov. Bill Weld's 71 percent win in 1994? The "Trump effect" of Democrats turning out because they're fed up with Washington could keep Baker below Weld's storied margin, Ubertaccio says.

The Warren report — Sen. Elizabeth Warren already said she's taking a look at running for president, and the way she went after Geoff Diehl on all things Trump made clear this election is a warm-up for 2020. I'll be looking to see what percentage of the vote she pulls in tonight, and further down the line, whether Massachusetts voters warm to her possible presidential ambitions.

The Trumpers — Despite Baker’s electoral success as a moderate, we’ve got a couple of candidates on the ballot today who embrace President Trump more willingly. Perhaps the most talked about is Geoff Diehl, the Republican taking on Sen. Elizabeth Warren. He was part of the president’s Massachusetts campaign, and Warren has labeled him a “rubber stamp” for Trump’s agenda. The other candidate embracing the president’s policies is hard-line Republican attorney from Bourne, Jay McMahon. He’s running for attorney general and rips on Attorney General Maura Healey’s assault weapons ban. I’m interested in the kind of numbers Diehl and McMahon get. Remember when far-right Republican for governor Scott Lively pulled in 36 percent of the vote in the Republican primary? Now we’ll get a look at something close to a baseline, pro-Trump GOP vote in Massachusetts.

The new additions to the delegation — A congressional seat is open in the 3rd District, where Democrat Lori Trahan, Republican Rick Green and Independent Michael Mullen are on the ballot. Another interesting congressional race worth keeping an eye on is in the state's 9th District, where Rep. Bill Keating faces Republican challenger Peter Tedeschi. The two districts encompass some of the state's more conservative pockets, and if there are any surprises tonight, they could happen here, MassInc pollster Steve Koczela told me. Democrat Ayanna Pressley is running unopposed in the 7th District after unseating Rep. Mike Capuano in the primary.

The ballot questions — Does Question 1, the nurse patient staffing level question, prevail despite weakening public support shown in polling over the last several weeks? How many people vote "yes" on Question 3, and what's the party breakdown?

How do Moulton's Serve America candidates do? — Rep. Seth Moulton has been raising money and traveling for Democratic candidates endorsed by his Serve America PAC this cycle. How many of Moulton's more than 70 picks win tonight?

Clark's Blue Wave — Rep. Katherine Clark has spent the last two years helping Democrats across the country flip their districts from red to blue. I'm looking to see how many of these candidates are successful. If we do see a blue wave, Clark will have had a hand in its success.

The Democrats coming for the Beacon Hill GOP — There's a group of Democratic women taking on Republicans on Beacon Hill. I'll keep an eye out for challengers Becca Rausch, Tram Nguyen and Katie McBrine. It's hard to beat incumbents, but these women may capture the support of voters who are heading to the polls because they're fed up with the Trump administration, and those who have become more involved in local politics since the 2016 election.

Year of the woman? — If all 83 women running for the legislature win tonight, they'd raise the percentage of female lawmakers to 39 percent, according a report from the Center for Women in Politics and Public Policy. That's not exactly gender parity, but a greater number of women running and winning will change the makeup of the talent pool for committee chairmanships, leadership positions and candidacies for higher office.

Eye on 2020 — Will anybody announce a presidential run bright and early on Wednesday morning, or will we get some time to rest? New Hampshire political strategist Jim Demers says you can count on potential candidates coming to New Hampshire for the rest of the year, but formal announcements likely won't come until 2019. Translation: Catch up on the new season of House of Cards while you can.

Can’t get enough of election night? The POLITICO team in D.C. and across the country will have the latest results with updating House and Senate maps throughout the night, as well as live analysis where we’ll be taking your questions and talking about the biggest takeaways.

Have a tip, story, suggestion, birthday, anniversary, new job, or any other nugget for the Playbook? Get in touch: smurray@politico.com.

President Donald Trump had dialed up his campaign schedule over the campaign season's home stretch, packing in 11 rallies in eight states over the final six days of the campaign. | Andrew Harnik/AP photo white house Trump's Election Day plans include monitoring races, watching returns with friends

After crisscrossing the country almost daily in the final weeks of the midterm campaign, President Donald Trump will spend Election Day monitoring key races and watching returns with family and friends, the White House said.

The president dialed up his campaign schedule over the season's homestretch, packing in 11 rallies in eight states over the final six days of the campaign. On Monday, the president made his final blitz, holding three rallies in three states for Senate and gubernatorial candidates.

Story Continued Below

“After 11 rallies in 8 states and weeks of campaigning for Republican candidates, the President will spend today making phone calls, monitoring Congressional, Senate and Gubernatorial races across the country and meeting with his political team for real-time updates,” press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said in a statement. “Later this evening the President and First Lady have invited family and friends to join them in the residence as they watch election returns.”

Most polls predict that while Republicans are likely to retain their majority in the Senate, the House may flip to Democratic control, a result that would put Tuesday's elections in line with historical trends. Trump has cast the midterms, repeatedly and loudly, as a referendum on his presidency in an effort to drive his voters to the polls.

“In a certain way, I am on the ballot,” Trump said in a Monday conference call with supporters. “Whether we consider it or not, the press is very much considering it a referendum on me and us as a movement.”

Playbook PM Sign up for our must-read newsletter on what's driving the afternoon in Washington. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

The White House has hailed Trump’s involvement on the campaign trail but has more recently been careful to distance itself somewhat from races that could land in the Democratic column on Tuesday.

Trump, in his closing message, drilled into the issue of illegal immigration, a red-meat issue for his base, as well as the strength of the economy. Top House Republicans reportedly pleaded with the president in the final days of the campaign to steer away from harsh immigration rhetoric in order to avoid alienating suburban voters the GOP needs if it is to retain control of the House.

Across the final days of the campaign, Trump had also appeared to lay the groundwork to claim that voter fraud took place if Republicans perform poorly in the midterms, warning Monday that he had alerted law enforcement to be on high alert for “illegal voting,” despite evidence suggesting that voter fraud is extremely rare. The Justice Department on Monday announced a list of 35 jurisdictions in 19 states where it would deploy personnel to “monitor compliance with the federal voting rights laws.”

POLITICO Playbook: Happy Election Day Presented by

President Donald Trump departs a campaign rally for Republican Senate candidate Mike Braun in Fort Wayne, Ind., on Nov. 5. | Aaron Bernstein/Getty Images

DRIVING THE DAY

HAPPY ELECTION DAY. After nearly two years of PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP executing his vision for America, voters will get a chance to decide whether they are happy with the direction of the country, or if they want to break up Republican Washington.

BUT ALSO, today could mark the final gasp of a House Republican majority that was built in 2010 principally on repealing Obamacare, cutting government spending and opening up the legislative process. Now, eight years later, not only have Republicans failed to repeal Obamacare, they are getting hammered over their opposition to the Affordable Care Act and some of its key provisions on the campaign trail. Government spending is through the roof. And critics complain that the legislative process is as closed as ever before.

THERE IS NO TRUE geographical consistency to where Republicans are struggling. They have their backs against the wall in Southern California, suburban Chicago, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Iowa, Georgia, North Carolina, New York, New Jersey and even Texas.

-- CHARLIE MAHTESIAN: “10 places where the 2018 midterms will be won and lost”: “Upstate New York … Downstate Illinois … Delaware Valley … Orange County, California … Metro Atlanta … Las Vegas … Maricopa County, Arizona … North Jersey … Oakland County, Michigan … Greater Houston.”

IF REPUBLICANS LOSE THE HOUSE -- which most insiders believe they will -- look for the White House to make the argument that this was in line with historical norms. And there is some truth to that. But the economy is clicking unlike ever before, and giving roughly two dozen seats back to Democrats under those circumstances would be somewhat atypical.

WAPO’S PAUL KANE: "If Democrats seize the House majority, it will mark the third time in 12 years that the chamber switched control, a level of voter volatility not seen since just after World War II.” WaPo

FRONT PAGE OF TODAY’S POLITICO, banner headline: “Will it be a wave?”

THE SENATE IS TIGHT, but most handicappers expect Republicans to keep or expand their narrow majority.

LINE OF THE DAY -- WAPO’S JOSH DAWSEY (@jdawsey1): “‘The midterm elections used to be like boring,’ Trump said. ‘...Who ever heard of midterm?’ ‘Now it’s like the hottest thing,’ he said of midterm elections. ‘These people are making a fortune,’ he says of the media.”

THE NEW CONGRESS will come to town next week for its orientation. House Republicans will hold their leadership elections on Wednesday, Nov. 14.

BEHIND THE SCENES … NO HEDGING HERE … DCCC CHAIRMAN BEN RAY LUJAN (D-N.M.) and HOUSE MINORITY LEADER NANCY PELOSI (D-CALIF.) held a conference call yesterday afternoon for hundreds of DCCC staff and volunteers. During the call, Lujan publicly declared he would be voting for Pelosi to be the next speaker of the House, according to a participant on the call. Lujan voting for Pelosi isn’t surprising, since the two allies have been working closely this entire cycle. But, it still sends a strong signal going into election night after months of coverage focused on candidates who have distanced themselves from the leader.

WHAT DEMOCRATS ARE CHATTERING ABOUT … NBC’S JON ALLEN (@jonallendc): “NEWS TO ME: I thought it took a majority of the House to be elected Speaker. It does not. Here’s how it works. Each member is called by name. When his or her turn comes, he or she calls out the name of his or her choice for Speaker. However, a member can pass ...

"If a candidate for Speaker wins a majority of the votes of those who call out a surname during the roll call of members, he or she is the Speaker. It is not a majority of the whole House. If someone votes ‘present,’ his or her vote does not count.”

BUZZ: WE HEAR that several members of Congress are slated to fly to Paris later this week as part of a trip organized by the Ripon Society. The trip, which also includes K Streeters and corporate types, comes as leadership races will have just begun. And, we might not even know who holds the majority in the House. THE PRESIDENT is also scheduled to be in Paris this weekend.

CHANGE IS A-COMING … WAPO’S ELISE VIEBECK: “A day before the election, some results are clear: The next Congress will be younger, more female and more diverse”: “A Latina state senator taking over for a white congressman in Texas who has served 13 terms.
