MIDTERMS WATCH

WHAT DEMOCRATS MIGHT DO WITH A MAJORITY: Last year Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer pledged that labor would sit “at the top of our list early January 2019” if Democrats won back the majority.

A review of Democrats’ labor bills over the past two years offers a roadmap for what’s in store, POLITICO’s Ian Kullgren writes. The proposals would end right-to-work, overturn key Supreme Court decisions, strengthen the NLRB and unions’ power in the workplace, among other things; none of them, however, is likely to go further than the House if the Senate remains Republican, as forecast. More here.

BOOMING ECONOMY UNDER GOP OBSCURED BY TRUMP: The GOP couldn’t have asked for a better jobs report Friday, with wages in October rising 3.1 percent over the previous year and the economy adding 250,000 new jobs.

And yet, the booming economy has not been an especially prominent theme of President Donald Trump’s campaign rhetoric. “Instead,” Ian Kullgren writes, “Trump has focused on a caravan of Central American migrants heading north to the U.S. border; on a constitutionally dubious threat to revoke birthright citizenship; on fomenting trade wars with Canada, Mexico, and China; and on a long-running battle with the Federal Reserve over raising interest rates.” More here.

Related read: “Fed Will Likely Raise Rates After Strong Jobs Report,” from the Wall Street Journal.

LEVIN’S SON COULD BECOME NEW VOICE ON LABOR: Andy Levin, the son of retiring Rep. Sander Levin (D-Mich.), is poised to become a new labor advocate in Congress. In August the younger Levin won the primary in his father’s Democratic district with 52 percent of the vote. Beyond his last name, Andy Levin a former union organizer and an attorney who sat on former President Bill Clinton’s labor law reform commission. Levin also worked at the AFL-CIO, where he pressed Congress to pass the Employee Free Choice Act (“card check”). That bill failed in the Senate by a narrow margin in 2007. Read an interview he gave Friday to the Macomb Daily here.

INSIDE DOL

NEW DRUG TESTING RULE: The Labor Department this morning will publish in the Federal Register a proposed regulation that would allow states to subject to drug testing a broad swath of applicants for unemployment insurance.

Under the 2012 Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act, Congress gave states the authority to drug test an applicant for unemployment benefits under limited circumstances — a Democratic concession to Republicans to in exchange for emergency spending on unemployment insurance. President Barack Obama’s Labor Department issued in 2016 a regulation that subjected relatively few categories of applicants to the drug tests. That didn’t sit well with Republicans, who after Trump took office repealed the rule under the Congressional Review Act.

Here’s the rub: Under the CRA, after a regulation is revoked federal agencies are barred from subsequently issuing a rule that is “substantially the same” — meaning DOL’s new version of the drug-test rule may be vulnerable to a court challenge. DOL says its new rule is “fundamentally different” from the previous rule, but some regulatory experts aren’t buying it. More here.

IMMIGRATION

PENTAGON REJECTED TROOP REQUEST AT FIRST: The Pentagon initially rejected the Department of Homeland Security’s request to send troops to the border, CNN reports.

“According to two defense official[s] familiar with the request, the Department of Homeland Security asked that the Pentagon provide a reserve force that could be called upon to provide ‘crowd and traffic control’ and safeguard Customs and Border Protection personnel at the border to counter a group of Central American migrants walking to the US border to request asylum,” CNN’s Ryan Browne and Nicole Gaouette report.

“The Pentagon rejected the request on October 26, according to one of the officials, even as it signed off on providing DHS with air and logistics support, medical personnel and engineers. The request was turned down because the Department of Defense felt that active duty troops do not have the authority to conduct that type of mission unless they are granted additional authorities by the President.” More here.

Related read: “Homeland security chief defends Trump's plan to send troops to border,” from the Guardian.

TEXAS FIRM WINS BORDER WALL CONTRACT: “A Texas company has been granted a $145 million federal contract to build six miles of wall along the U.S.-Mexico border in the Rio Grande Valley,” the Associated Press reports. “Galveston-based SLSCO will start construction of an 18-foot, reinforced concrete levee wall in February, the U.S. Customs and Border Patrol said.

“The project, which will take place in the agency's McAllen Station region, will also raise the height of existing fences. The wall will be the first section of President Donald Trump's border barriers in the Rio Grande Valley, which is the busiest corridor for illegal crossings.” More here.

THE BENEFITS OF A CARAVAN: Caravans like the one President Donald Trump has lambasted are becoming a more frequent way for migrants to travel north — perhaps with good reason, Anna-Catherine Brigida writes for the Washington Post.

“Caravans were once used sparingly to spotlight a particular problem,” Brigida writes. “A group of Central American mothers, for example, has traveled through Mexico each year for 14 years searching for sons and daughters who disappeared on the migrant trail. The Mesoamerican Caravan for a Good Life has organized migrant caravans for years, including one in March that gained international attention.

“But experts now predict that caravan-style treks could become a more frequent scene along the decades-old migration routes from the region. President Trump has reacted with combative and unsubstantiated claims that the migrants — including many families and children — pose a threat that requires military mobilization at the southern border.

“Still, the national attention has also brought awareness of the potential benefits of the caravans for migrants, such as increased safety along the route and shared resources. This could bring even more such groups in the future, migrant activists say.” More here.

Related read: “U.S. militia groups head to border, stirred by Trump’s call to arms,” from the Washington Post.

UNIONS

USW REACHES AGREEMENT WITH ARCELORMITTAL: “The United Steelworkers union and ArcelorMittal reached a tentative deal on a new labor contract covering about 15,000 workers after several months of negotiations,” the Wall Street Journal’s Patrick Thomas reports.

“The four-year agreement for workers includes wage increases between 3% and 4% each year and a $4,000 ratification bonus. The deal with ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steelmaker, comes less than a month after the union reached a similar agreement with workers from U.S. Steel Corp.

“Workers at the two largest U.S. steelmakers have been demanding higher compensation as tariffs on foreign metal push prices and profits to their highest point in years. Leaders of the nearly 30,000 member union say the company’s aren’t passing those benefits down to their workers.” More here.

THE ECONOMY

MILLENNIAL MEN AREN’T WORKING: “Ten years after the Great Recession, 25- to 34-year-old men are lagging in the workforce more than any other age and gender demographic,” Bloomberg’s Jeanna Smialek writes.

“About 500,000 more would be punching the clock today had their employment rate returned to pre-downturn levels. Many, like Butcher, say they’re in training. Others report disability. All are missing out on a hot labor market and crucial years on the job, ones traditionally filled with the promotions and raises that build the foundation for a career.” More here.

COMPANIES TELL EMPLOYEES: GO VOTE: “Ahead of the midterm elections, many companies are urging employees to cast their votes, banning meetings or giving people paid time off to do so,” the Wall Street Journal’s Chip Cutter reports. “Employers say they have a duty to encourage greater participation in democracy in a time of deep political division, especially because voter turnout is typically so much lower in midterms than presidential elections.

“At least 325 companies, from jeans brand Levi Strauss & Co. to spirits maker Diageo DEO, are giving employees paid time off to cast their ballots on Election Day or in early voting, according to the nonpartisan nonprofit Vote.org. Other employers are closing offices early on Nov. 6 or, in some cases, shutting down for the day.” More here.

What education wonks are watching on Election Day

With help from Kimberly Hefling

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Education is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Education subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

WHAT EDUCATION WONKS ARE WATCHING ON ELECTION DAY: Tomorrow is Election Day, in case you haven’t been conscious lately. While education may not be a top issue driving people to the polls (according to one POLITICO/Morning Consult poll) and may have been far overshadowed by health care on the campaign trail, it has been a talker in many state and federal races.

— Teacher strikes, teacher pay, teachers running for office, public education funding, debt-free college and school safety have all played out in congressional, gubernatorial and down-ballot races this cycle. So Morning Education reached out to a variety of education wonks to see what they’re watching on Election Day and in the weeks to come.

— A lot of the interesting stuff is in the states. Education wonks are monitoring the outcomes of gubernatorial and state legislative races for actual consequences when it comes to schools and education policy. POLITICO’s Morning Score reports that, when it comes to statehouses, Democrats are hoping to flip “6-8 chambers … and around 300-350 state legislative seats from red to blue,” said Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee Executive Director Jessica Post. “We know it’ll be an uphill battle,” she continued, saying maps have been drawn to favor Republicans. “But we feel great about our chances.”

— If a blue wave materializes, expect school funding to keep coming up. “So many governorships and state legislatures are currently controlled by the GOP that if there were a wave, we could see a dramatic shift in what policy reforms are prioritized in the states,” said Andy Smarick, director of civil society, education and work at the R Street Institute, a conservative think tank. “We might expect a couple years’ worth of fights over teacher pay increases and changes to state funding formulas for K-12 education.”

— Again, watch for school funding reform: “If there's a blue wave and we see Democratic governors and Democratic legislatures in more places, expect policymakers to open the public's checkbook for increases in school spending,” said Michael Petrilli, president of the Thomas B. Fordham Institute, a conservative education think tank. “Given that the economy is red-hot and state finances are in better shape than they have been for a decade — a situation that is unlikely to last — now is the time to get funding increases, and funding reform, done.”

— School choice advocates are counting on Republicans in down-ballot races. “State elections always have the potential to shuffle the deck in state capitals, which could have major implications for private school choice programs and charter schools in 2019,” said John Schilling, president of the American Federation for Children, the school choice advocacy group formerly chaired by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos.

—“There are historic numbers of open state legislative seats across our target states, and based on our polling and grassroots efforts, we see a lot of momentum to create and expand educational options among candidates and certainly among voters when the legislative sessions convene in January.”

GOOD MONDAY MORNING, NOV. 5. My local polling place is an adorable STEM magnet school behind my apartment. My husband and I have a tradition of voting as early as possible while still in sweatpants and then treating ourselves to breakfast sandwiches and iced coffee. Happy Election Day to all! Share your predictions with me: cemma@politico.com or @caitlinzemma. Send events to: educalendar@politicopro.com. And follow us on Twitter: @Morning_Edu and @POLITICOPro.

Just in time to help policy professionals and business leaders in the Golden State navigate the twists and turns of a new administration, POLITICO California Pro is the only tool that will arm you with a team of state-level experts. Learn more.

MIDTERMS WATCH

STATE RACES COULD MEAN CHANGES FOR ESSA PLANS: Oh, we’re not done with what education wonks are watching. State races could also have a major impact on the plans that states developed for holding schools accountable under the Every Student Succeeds Act, said Phillip Lovell, vice president of policy development and government relations for the Alliance for Excellent Education, an education advocacy group closely tracking those plans. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has approved every single one of them, but new leadership could open them up to changes.

— New Mexico’s ESSA plan could see the biggest changes. Polls earlier this year showed the governor’s race was a dead heat, and a recent poll shows Democratic Rep. Michelle Lujan Grisham pulling away from her opponent Republican Rep. Steve Pearce. But the state’s ESSA plan could change no matter who wins.

— “The Democratic legislature is salivating at the prospect of making major changes to New Mexico’s accountability system under a new governor, despite the gains made by the state in recent years and the commitment to equity clearly articulated in the current plan,” Lovell said. Teacher evaluations tied to student test scores have been especially controversial in New Mexico, with teachers burning their evaluations in protest in recent years. Both gubernatorial candidates have shown an interest in scrapping the Common Core-aligned PARCC test and overhauling the state’s teacher evaluation system.

WHAT FEDERAL RACES WILL MEAN FOR DEVOS AND LEGISLATION: Education wonks, like everyone else, will be keeping an eye on changes in the political makeup and leadership of the House and Senate.

—“Some of our biggest progress in federal education policy came when congressional leadership was split, one chamber R, one chamber D, and I see a good chance at some progress on bills like [the Higher Education Act] and [the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act] under this scenario,” said Noelle Ellerson, associate executive director of policy and advocacy for AASA: The School Superintendents Association, which represents school district superintendents nationwide.

— DeVos under the microscope: “A blue wave election, with Democrats taking control of the House, won't stop the Trump administration from pursuing its preferred policies — whether deregulation of higher education, drastic cuts to education funding, or reorganization of key offices — but it could increase the political costs of doing so,” said Anne Hyslop, a former Obama education official now with the Alliance for Excellent Education.

— “Once in the majority, Democrats can hold public oversight hearings with Education Department officials, subpoena documents, call for monitoring reports and audits, and more — a level of pressure Secretary DeVos really hasn’t faced since her nomination. Of course, divided government will also dramatically change the dynamics for major legislative efforts, like HEA reauthorization, giving Democrats more leverage to insert their priorities into any overhaul.”

WHAT THE MIDTERMS COULD MEAN FOR APPROPRIATIONS: Rep. Nita Lowey (D-N.Y.) is expected to become chairwoman of the House Appropriations Committee if her party wins the House majority. Such a victory would put Democrats in a position to fend off the last bout of sequestration, try their luck at restoring earmarks and use the power of the purse to hold the Trump administration “accountable,” Lowey told Pro budget reporter Jennifer Scholtes.

— “With Republicans in charge, we have frankly leapt from fiscal crisis to fiscal crisis,” Lowey said. “And many of the shutdowns and the continuing resolution are the direct result of the Budget Control Act of 2011, S. 365 (112), which left us with unworkable caps on defense and non-defense spending.”

— “Even with two-year budget deals that sought to dampen the effect of the 2011 law, non-defense spending remains below 2010 levels,” she said. “So if you adjust for inflation, in my judgment — and I think for most Democrats — we still aren’t serving enough children in after-school programs, Head Start. Roads, bridges, tunnels are in terrible shape. And we want to make sure that we deal with that.” More.

TEACHERS UNIONS MAKE LAST PUSH: The leaders of the nation’s two largest teachers unions made their final GOTV pushes this weekend. Both unions campaigned for Democrat Andrew Gillum, who’s locked in a close race against Republican Ron DeSantis for Florida governor, and Gretchen Whitmer, who has maintained a lead over Republican Attorney General Bill Schuette in the Michigan governor’s race.

— National Education Association President Lily Eskelsen García went to Las Vegas, Phoenix and Miami this weekend, backing teachers running for office and, in Florida, Gillum. NEA Vice President Becky Pringle campaigned in Michigan for Whitmer.

— American Federation of Teachers President Randi Weingarten spent Friday in Connecticut for Democrat Ned Lamont, who’s in a close race against Republican Bob Stefanowski for governor. She spent the weekend in Florida for Gillum and she’s headed to Michigan today for Whitmer.

— Their civic duty: Eskelsen García will spend Election Day in D.C., where she plans to vote, and Weingarten is headed back to New York to cast her ballot.

IRS TO HEAR FROM EDUCATION ADVOCATES: In non-midterm news, the IRS today will hold a public hearing on a proposed rule that seeks to limit the federal deductibility of contributions to charitable organizations. The Treasury Department published the rule in August and the agency received more than 7,000 comments — many from school choice backers who oppose the rule and voucher opponents who support it.

— Some context: Eighteen states have tax credit scholarship programs that award individuals or businesses a full or partial tax credit when they donate to organizations that grant private school scholarships. About a dozen of them issue full tax credits to donors and combined with the federal deduction, the tax benefits can exceed the size of the donation.

— The proposed rule, aimed at preventing efforts by some blue states to get around a new limit on state and local tax deductions, would prevent donors who contribute to state tax credit scholarship programs from reaping such a benefit. School choice advocates worry the rule will make taxpayers less likely to donate to organizations that award private school scholarships because of the reduced tax benefit, ultimately hurting students, many of whom come from low-income families.

— Twenty-five people are scheduled to testify at today’s hearing and it looks like school choice could dominate the discussion. Among them are a student, parent and graduate of the Alabama Opportunity Scholarship Fund, which provides tax credited private school scholarships to students in the state. Executive Director Lesley Searcy, who’s attending the hearing, said she hopes they’ll “put a human face on this issue.” Leslie Hiner, vice president of legal affairs for the Indianapolis-based advocacy group EdChoice, is also scheduled to testify.

— On the flip side, Sasha Pudelski, advocacy director for AASA, The School Superintendents Association, will thank the IRS for shutting down “a tax shelter for educational scholarship programs.” Marc Egan, the National Education Association’s director of government affairs, is also scheduled to testify. Check out the list of speakers.

MOVERS AND SHAKERS

— Former North Carolina Gov. Beverly Perdue has been appointed to serve as chairwoman of the National Assessment Governing Board, DeVos announced on Friday. Perdue will be the first female chair in the 30-year history of the board, which sets policy for the National Assessment of Educational Progress, or the Nation’s Report Card.

— F. Javier Cevallos, president of Framingham State University in Massachusetts, has assumed the chair of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities’ board of directors.

REPORT ROLL CALL

— The National Association for College Admission Counseling has released a new research brief that finds the intensity of the political climate has led to an increase in activism at 52 percent of all secondary schools.

SYLLABUS

— DeVos family pumps big bucks into GOP campaigns as Dems bemoan influence: The Detroit News.

— Justices Sonia Sotomayor, Neil Gorsuch on promoting education in citizenship: CBS.

— California gubernatorial candidate Gavin Newsom pushes big-budget early childhood education agenda in closing days of campaign: Los Angeles Times.

— In New York City schools, 40,000 students aren’t getting required special education services, report finds: Chalkbeat.

— Florida Gov. Rick Scott calls for funding to harden schools in rural districts: Tampa Bay Times.

— New York City Department of Education probed for pitching charters to public school kids: New York Post.

— College athletes three times more likely to be named in Title IX sexual misconduct complaints: ESPN.

The status of, and threats against, midterm election security

With help from Eric Geller and Martin Matishak

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

BRACING FOR TOMORROW’S BIG DAY — Let’s look at the state of election security and the chief threats going into Election Day.

— Where we’re at: There have been improvements since 2016, most agree, but not nearly enough. “I think we've made great progress, particularly at the individual polling stations and in the tabulation of votes,” top Senate Intelligence Democrat Mark Warner said on CBS’s “Face the Nation” on Sunday. The National Association of Secretaries of State late last week touted the state-federal relationship, something few would’ve done in 2016. And DHS Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen boasted that the midterms would be the the most secure ever.

“I am concerned that this White House, though, has frankly held back,” Warner said, pointing to White House resistance to the most prominent election security bill in Congress (S. 2593). Few states have implemented post-election risk-limiting audits to safeguard against tampering, and some still use particularly vulnerable paperless voting machines. Texas and Georgia already have seen voting glitches on such machines, as POLITICO’s Christian Vasquez and Matthew Choi reported Sunday. At least two other states had been using file-sharing software on state election servers that made them vulnerable in other ways, Pro Publica reported late last week. Vendor and candidate cybersecurity remain among the least addressed areas.

The White House likewise has no strategy for combating election influence operations, as Eric reported. Social media giants are still wrestling to control such meddling attempts, with Twitter deleting 10,000 accounts over the past two months that mostly posed as Democrats and discouraged voters from heading to the polls, Reuters reported late last week.

— The known threat: We know there was a successful cyberattack against Knox County, Tenn., during the primaries. Likewise, DHS circulated a report on seeing a “growing” number of attempted attacks on state and local election system during the midterms, which the department said was a product of improved information sharing rather than evidence of an uptick. The Boston Globe today reported in greater detail on DHS memos to election officials and law enforcement.

On the candidate side, hackers caused trouble for three California Democratic House candidates during the primaries. Sen. Claire McCaskill, one of the nation’s more vulnerable Democrats, said hackers went after her office network, as did Sen. Jeanne Shaheen, although Google alerts about attempted attacks to senatorial offices of both parties make it hard to draw conclusions about whether the hackers were trying to meddle in the election or conduct more routine cyber espionage. Another vulnerable Democrat, Sen. Joe Manchin, last week said his social media accounts were hacked, but he offered few details.

Russia, Iran and China are all trying to influence the midterms, U.S. intelligence and law enforcement leaders declared last month. New charges unsealed against a Russian woman last month provided details about the scope of Russia’s alleged interference operation in this election cycle. Facebook late last month removed 82 pages tied to Iran over “inauthentic activity” designed to sow discord ahead of the elections. There’s widespread skepticism about the administration’s claims about Chinese interference, however.

— The unknown threat: Despite plenty to worry about, the 2018 interference we’ve seen so far pales in comparison to the 2016 meddling, prompting some degree of bafflement and speculation. Perhaps Russia is waiting until the last minute, some say. Perhaps their hackers have been more discreet this time around. Perhaps they’re gearing up for the juicier 2020 presidential race. One of the main Russian hacking groups accused of nefarious activity during the 2016 campaign might have resumed an emphasis on cyber espionage rather than disruption, if their detected activity elsewhere in the world offers hints.

HAPPY MONDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! BOLD ELECTION PREDICTION: Some candidates will lose, and yet others will win. You heard it here first. SECOND TIME’S THE CHARM? — Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp on Sunday again leveled a major hacking allegation without evidence, following his disproven allegations against DHS in 2016 with identical charges that the state Democratic party tried to break into the state voter registration system. Kemp happens to be running on the GOP ticket for governor at the same time he’s holding the secretary job. Naturally, Democrats called it a political stunt, and pointed to Kemp’s history of cyber missteps in the office, and things only got more contentious as the day went on. Cybersecurity experts and researchers took offense, especially given the status of Kemp’s website security in a state often criticized by election integrity groups as among the worst in the nation.

The announcement of the investigation came shortly after attorneys suing Kemp on behalf of Georgia voters notified his office of a voter registration system vulnerability that they say could render millions unable to vote, one of the lawyers, David Cross, said. "Everyone's focused on the wrong thing and doing exactly what Kemp wants," Cross told POLITICO. "He was worried the vulnerability was going to come to light and he wanted to get ahead of it and have the story focused on something else."

Cross said a Georgia voter noticed the state's My Voter page didn't require verification of his identity while he was seeking his own voter registration information, and that anyone could access voters' personal data through the vulnerability, and alter it. The resident sought out one of Cross's clients, and the attorneys spoke to the voter Friday afternoon. The attorneys then notified the FBI and Kemp's outside counsel on Saturday, Cross said, and gave them the voter's information.Meanwhile, the resident also contacted the Democratic party as another avenue of addressing it, Cross said.

The vulnerability remains, Cross said: "Nothing has been done. Nobody has contacted the Georgia resident. We tried to keep it out of the press because we don't want the vulnerabilities to be known around the world."

But Kemp's office said there was an attempt to breach the My Voter system. "We opened an investigation into the Democratic Party of Georgia after receiving information from our legal team about failed efforts to breach the online voter registration system and My Voter Page," the office said later Sunday. "We are working with our private sector vendors and investigators to review data logs. We have contacted our federal partners and formally requested the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate these possible cyber crimes. The Secretary of State's office will release more information as it becomes available."

WE RECOMMEND WILLIAM JAMES’ ‘WILL TO BELIEVE’ — U.S. IT professionals don’t have much confidence in governments’ ability to securely administer elections, according to a new survey coming out today from ISACA, a group that represents tech pros. Of the nearly 2,000 surveyed, 86 percent said they were concerned about the public sector’s capability to conduct reliable and accurate elections.

READY FOR THE COUNTER-CYBERATTACK — The U.S. intelligence community and the DoD have reportedly agreed on a plan to strike at Russia if Moscow attempts to interfere in the midterms. While details are slim, the joint Center for Public Integrity and Daily Beast story published late last week found that American hackers have been given the greenlight to go after Russia’s digital systems if the Kremlin tries to meddle. The plan is in keeping with the Trump administration’s steps to unshackle U.S. military offensive digital operations, starting with the decision to replace an Obama-era directive governing offensive and defensive digital operations with one that gives DoD a freer hand to engage.

BITING ON FAKES — Presented with screenshots of 11 emails, Americans could only identify fakes correctly about half the time, according to a study by Valimail released late last week. People were less likely to spot fake emails that jived with their political beliefs; for instance, Democrats could spot a fake email from Beto O’Rourke 36 percent of the time, while Republicans could spot a fake email from Ted Cruz 20 percent of the time.

"The results of this survey confirm what nation-states and bad actors have known for years: that email is incredibly vulnerable to impersonation, and is therefore a prime channel for spreading misinformation, malware, and fraud,” said Alexander García-Tobar, CEO and co-founder of Valimail. “More concerning is the fact that consumers’ trust in their public leaders and political candidates can be so easily abused for financial or political gain, when the tools to combat these types of attacks are readily available.”

STEADY AS SHE GOES — After a year of changes in the ways that federal agencies assess their cybersecurity posture, the Office of Management and Budget is looking forward to agencies reporting that data in a more stable way over the next few years. The 2018 fiscal year “was a big change year,” Derek Larson, deputy director for cybersecurity risk and performance management at OMB, told the Information Security and Privacy Advisory Board late last week. “FY2019 — we’re looking for it to be a lot more consistent.”

OMB will continue to tweak agencies’ assessment criteria, known as Federal Information Security Modernization Act, or FISMA, metrics; the office issued new guidance to agencies on Oct. 25. But Larson told the board that recent updates to the metrics — including a new focus on “high-value assets” and a shift of assessment responsibility from chief information officers to inspectors general — had paved the way for a more accurate understanding of where agencies stood. “We really want to try and be more constant from 2018 to 2019,” he said, “so we can really get that trend data to see how agencies are improving.”

SPY GAMES — A compromised internet messaging service reportedly allowed China and Iran to roll up dozens of CIA agents. Former officials say in a Yahoo news story from late last week that they believe the breach started with an Iranian double agent who was hired by the clandestine agency. The agent showed Iranian intelligence the website the CIA used for their communications, which Tehran then penetrated through a series of Google searches. The breach also led to China’s penetration of the CIA network in that country, resulting in the death of approximately 30 agency spies.

TWEET OF THE DAY — *holds breath*

How farm bureaus spent campaign cash

With help from Helena Bottemiller Evich and Maya Parthasarathy

IN THE HOPPER: In an election cycle where a number of farm-state midterm races could be critical to determining control of Congress, state farm bureaus in the biggest ag states spread their campaign contributions to agriculture lawmakers on both sides, though Republicans got more.

— The soda wars’ latest battle will be decided Tuesday when voters in Oregon and Washington choose whether to ban new taxes on sugary drinks and other groceries.

— Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue called the Florida gubernatorial election “so cotton-pickin’ important” at a rally on Saturday, adding a new racially charged controversy to a contest that was already smoldering with racial tensions.

— USDA’s inspector general will probe the department’s controversial plans to relocate a pair of research agencies out of the D.C. area. The IG investigation could spur new congressional scrutiny of Perdue’s proposal.

HOW FARM BUREAUS SPENT CAMPAIGN CASH: Influential ag groups have been selective — and bipartisan — in handing out cash to candidates in the many competitive midterm races in farm states and districts this cycle.

Farm bureaus in the top 10 agricultural states spent more than $1 million through federal PACs ahead of Tuesday’s elections, our Liz Crampton reports this morning. Here’s where the money went:

— Most contributions went to Republicans, but nearly all the farm bureaus donated to both parties. The majority of donations were relatively small, between $1,000 and $10,000.

— Texas and California farm bureaus gave about $558,000 and $210,000, respectively, far outpacing other states.

The top individual recipient among the “Big Four” agriculture committee leaders was Senate Agriculture ranking member Debbie Stabenow, who took in about $18,000 in donations from six of the 10 states POLITICO surveyed.

— The Michigan Democrat is seeking reelection in a state President Donald Trump won in 2016, though Stabenow is widely favored to prevail. Senate Ag Chairman Pat Roberts (R-Kan.) is not up for reelection this year.

Out-of-state spending: Most donations stayed within state boundaries, but ag policymakers and party leaders in competitive races — like Senate Ag member Deb Fischer (R-Neb.) and House Rules Chairman Pete Sessions (R-Texas) — also raked in campaign funds from farm bureaus elsewhere.

Liz has more details here for Pros.

ON THE BALLOT: FUTURE OF THE SODA WARS: The entire West Coast could soon be off-limits to new soda taxes, if voters in Washington and Oregon on Tuesday approve statewide ballot initiatives, our Helena Bottemiller Evich reports.

The results could reverberate across other states, as the beverage industry, which has spent big to promote the measures, increasingly seeks to take additional states off the potential tax map by pursuing state-level bans on new levies.

Has the momentum shifted? The California legislature this year approved a controversial ban on new food or beverage taxes through 2031. The surprise move followed a series of recent wins for the pro-tax camp, from San Francisco to Philadelphia. Michigan and Arizona have both passed statewide bans on new food and drink taxes within the last year.

An expensive fight: In Washington, beverage companies have poured more than $20 million into supporting Initiative 1634, outspending opponents more than 200 to 1. In Oregon, opponents of Measure 103 have raised $7.5 million (some of which will go towards other ballot measures), while supporters raised $5.7 million.

State of play: Polls have been few, but mixed. Measure 103 in Oregon could be close. Opposition to Initiative 1634 was ahead by 20 points, per one poll a few weeks ago.

— Former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg chipped in $2.1 million to oppose the Oregon measure.

— Washington’s ballot initiative wouldn’t scuttle Seattle’s soda tax, which kicked in earlier this year, but it would stop other localities from following the city’s lead. Read Helena’s full story here.

PERDUE CRITICIZED FOR ‘COTTON-PICKIN’’ COMMENT: The agriculture secretary and former Georgia governor is facing a backlash after he described the heated Florida gubernatorial race as “so cotton-pickin’ important” at a rally Saturday for GOP candidate Ron DeSantis. The comment, reported by POLITICO Florida’s Matt Dixon, added a new layer of race-related controversy to a campaign where race has been a major factor. It was also a rare case of the normally under-the-radar USDA chief causing national controversy.

“Public policy matters. Leadership matters. And that is why this election is so cotton-pickin’ important to the state of Florida,” Perdue told supporters in Lakeland, according to a recording provided by the liberal group American Bridge. “I hope you all don’t mess it up.”

— Democrat Andrew Gillum is running to be Florida’s first black governor. After the August primaries, DeSantis called Gillum “articulate” in a Fox News interview and said Florida voters shouldn’t “monkey this up” by electing the Democrat. During an Oct. 21 debate, Gillum accused DeSantis of attempting to “draw all the attention he can to the color of my skin.”

Perdue’s “cotton-pickin’” comment sparked headlines and online criticism throughout the weekend after it was first reported by POLITICO — an unusual occurrence for one of Trump’s steadiest Cabinet officials.

“I think there is certainly a throwback element to the language that we’re hearing coming out of the Republican party that is unfortunately disparaging to communities,” Stacey Abrams, who is running for Georgia governor and would be the country’s first black woman governor, said Sunday on CNN’s State of the Union. “It may be unintentional, but it signals a deeper misinformation about what Andrew Gillum can accomplish, what I can accomplish.”

A USDA spokesman did not respond, as of MA’s deadline Sunday night, to a request for comment on Perdue’s remark.

USDA RELOCATIONS GETTING WATCHDOG PROBE: The Agriculture Department’s inspector general will investigate whether USDA followed proper procedures when deciding to move the Economic Research Service and National Institute of Food and Agriculture outside of Washington — and whether the department has the authority to make the moves.

The IG investigation could potentially trigger stepped-up efforts by lawmakers to block or restrict Perdue’s decision to relocate the agencies in 2019, which has drawn criticism from members of Congress, ag research groups and former USDA staffers.

— Some appropriators who determine USDA’s budget have appeared skeptical of Perdue’s proposal. They could weigh in on the issue when Congress passes a final Agriculture-FDA spending bill.

— House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) and Del. Eleanor Holmes Norton said Friday that the department’s plans “appear suspicious because of the absence of an adequate explanation” for the move, POLITICO’s Sarah Zimmerman reports. They suggested USDA ignored protocol by “omitting required considerations, such as a robust cost-benefit analysis.”

— USDA has said that moving the agencies outside the Beltway will bring them closer to the farm communities they’re set up to serve, and also help attract new talent that might be turned off by D.C.’s high cost of living.

ROW CROPS

— Environmentalists ready for NAFTA 2.0 fight: Green groups are gearing up to fight the North American trade pact when lawmakers consider ratification next year. The active opposition could have major consequences for the deal’s fate in Congress — especially if Democrats win control of the House on Tuesday. Pro Trade’s Doug Palmer has the story.

— Zinke finds few defenders amid ethics scandals: Industry insiders and Trump allies think Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke might step down amid government watchdog probes into his potentially illegal or unethical actions, Pro Energy’s Zack Colman, Eric Wolff and Ben Lefebvre report.

— House Democrats’ spending agenda: Rep. Nita Lowey is likely to wield the House Appropriations gavel if Democrats take over the chamber next year. She told Pro Budget’s Jennifer Scholtes she’d rather see Congress close the book on fiscal 2019 during the lame duck, even though a December stopgap could give the party controlling the House more influence over unfinished spending levels next year. Full interview here.

— Trade turmoil and refinancing troubles: It will be “more challenging” for farmers to renegotiate current loans or borrow more this winter unless Trump can quickly cut deals to relieve tariff pressure, Kent Thiesse, a vice president and farm loan specialist at MinnStar Bank in Lake Crystal, Minn., told the Star-Tribune.

— New FDA guidance on added sugars: The agency posted final guidance on added-sugars labeling, including much detail on fruit-juice concentrates — along with draft guidance on serving sizes. Helena has the story.

— Combating diabetes: POLITICO convened a working group to explore the growing diabetes crisis that included congressional staff, federal health officials and medical providers. One in three U.S. adults (or 100 million people) is living with diabetes or prediabetes. Read the group’s discussion here.

— Trade mission to South Korea: Ken Isley, administrator of USDA’s Foreign Agricultural Service, leads a trade delegation in Seoul today through Thursday. Nearly 50 U.S. agribusinesses and farm groups are part of the trip. Check out the details.

— U.S., WTO nations pledge ag biotech cooperation: Thirteen World Trade Organization members signed a non-binding statement promoting agricultural biotechnology and seeking standard regulations. Sarah Zimmerman explains.

— Movers and shakers: Two CFOs of big-name companies — Kathy Waller (Coca-Cola) and Ned Segal (Twitter) — are joining Beyond Meat’s board of directors, Axios reports.

THAT’S ALL FOR MA! See you right here tomorrow. HARRIS, NEWSOM headline final efforts for Dems -- COX and DENHAM in the valley -- VOTER REGISTRATION numbers soar -- BROWN’s closing campaign argument Presented by California Resources Corporation

THE BUZZ: With the latest most important election of our lives days away, and California perhaps acting as the critical House majority hinge, it was a busy weekend for elected officials.

-- Lt. Gov Gavin Newsom and Sen. Kamala Harris teamed up on behalf of top priority congressional candidates during a SoCal swing, Carla reports from Irvine: “Newsom and Harris — once viewed as potential rivals for higher office — marshaled their growing star power on the campaign trail Saturday in a bid to boost Democrats' hopes in several congressional districts the party is aiming to flip en route to the House majority.

Story Continued Below

-- The barnstorm came as both Newsom, the California lieutenant governor, and Harris, the first-term senator, are increasingly positioned as representatives of a new generation of Democratic leaders. Once seen as competitors to move up the ranks of California politics, they've now both staked a claim as leaders of the “resistance” against Trump.” Read Carla Marinucci’s story in POLITICO here.

-- GOP Governor candidate John Cox was stumping forRepublicans like congressional contender Young Kim and endangered Rep. Jeff Denham — more on that below — as well as top legislative Republican candidates like state Sen. Andy Vidak, state Assembly candidate Bill Essayli and state Senate candidate Rob Poythress, who are central to the state GOP’s effort to blunt Democratic gains in Sacramento, as evidenced by the millions the state party has spent for them.

-- Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti has spent months crisscrossing the country to buoy fellow Dems. On Saturday he ventured closer to home, heading to San Diego County to lend his ascendant profile to Ammar Campa-Najjar as the Democrat seeks to unseat Rep. Duncan Hunter in a race increasingly marred by what the Campa-Najjar camp calls racist insinuations . Garcetti said he was seeking to rebut “the racism and falsehoods."

-- Tom Steyer isn’t on the ballot (this time), but the high-rolling Democratic powerbroker has spent millions to juice youth turnout — some $3.8 million in California alone, which his staff said has led to nearly 30,000 new registrations. Punctuating that effort, he was in in southern California on Saturday to launch a GOTV effort and canvass in CA-39, where Dem Gil Cisneros is vying with Kim for Rep. Ed Royce’s soon-to-be-former seat.

-- State Sen. Kevin de León also joined Cisneros on Saturday and then teamed up with Democratic state Senate candidate Bob Archuleta — who’s seeking the seat former state Sen. Tony Mendoza forfeited amid sexual harassment allegations — Campa-Najjar, state superintendent contender Tony Thurmond and state Sen. Ricardo Lara, a top legislative ally seeking to be insurance commissioner. An illness kept Sen. Dianne Feinstein off the trail.

-- Gov. Jerry Brown stayed focused on repelling Proposition 6, which would repeal the transit-funding gas tax that Brown helped muscle through the Legislature. In his first campaign appearance of the general election, the governor rallied in Palo Alto on Friday to urge a “no” vote — his first campaign event since the post-primary Dem unity rally back in June (an ad with Brown making the case also dropped last week). “It’s dangerous, and it was cooked up by some shady politicians who used their campaign funds because they thought they could fool the people,” Brown said.

QUOTE OF THE DAY: “If the Republicans want to spend $100 million criticizing me, demonizing me, I must be pretty important.” House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, on the eve of potentially reclaiming the Speaker’s gavel, to the NYTimes.

TRAIL MIX

FROM THE COX CARAVAN IN MODESTO: Cox and Rep. Jeff Denham had almost finished their campaign speeches when Sharon Rubio decided to speak up. “What about support for our president?” the 44-year-old accountant shouted. “What about a little support for Trump?”

-- Her frustration reflected a recurring dynamic of this congressional race, one of several California contests that have attracted unprecedented amounts of money: the delicate dance with, and around, a polarizing President. Red MAGA hats were sprinkled throughout the audience in a sun-baked shopping center here. But Cox and Denham, dressed in matching outfits of blue checkered shirts tucked into jeans, kept their focus on local issues and largely eschewed mentioning the occupant of the White House.

-- Denham referenced Trump having signed measures intended to increase water deliveries for agriculture -- an existential issue in an agricultural area where the city’s motto starts with the word “Water” and thirsty nut trees are an economic pillar -- but eschewed mentioning “the president” by name. Red MAGA hats were sprinkled throughout the audience in a sun-baked shopping center here. FROM THE NEWSOM/HARRIS TOUR IN IRVINE: East Bay Rep. Eric Swalwell showed up to support Democrat Katie Porter and spoke to POLITICO about his 2020 plans, saying he’ll decide on a run “probably just after the New Year.... I’ve been to Iowa about 12 times and I’ve got a full-time staff there,” he said, "showing that winning the path through the House means running a 50 state strategy. I’ve been to Alabama and Indiana and Tennessee in the last two years,’’ states Democrats need to focus on. And “what I hear there is that the economy is not the unemployment rate, it’s not the stock market and it’s not the GDP....It’s how people are doing in their lives...when the president talks about those numbers, people want them to actually mean something.” See our #ShakyHandProduction video here.

THE UNSUNG HEROES – They don’t get the photo ops, the selfies or the TV air time, but it’s folks like Joe Shea, 24, who are really running the big campaigns up and down this state. Shea, a former barista who worked all night and interned all day to get a foot in the political campaign door, has become Team Newsom’s undisputed jack-of-all-trades. As its Southern California field director, the ever-upbeat Shea races cellphone in hand, coordinating candidates’ teams, checking data, posting signs, assembling guests and GOTV lists and handling logistical nightmares that pop up – as in this weekend in Costa Mesa, where he not only ordered four dozen pizzas from the local Pizza Hut, but walked them over to feed hungry canvassers at the Harley Rouda headquarters.

VOTER STATS: Turnout will still be critical, but more Californians will eligible to vote Tuesday than for any gubernatorial election in nearly 70 years, per the secretary of state’s office. Just over 78 percent of eligible Californians are signed up, which means nearly 1.9 million more than in 2014.

-- Broken down by party, there are about 850,000 registered Democrats than four years ago and about 200,000 more than there were in September; Republicans have lost around 270,000 voters since the eve of the last gubernatorial election but have added some 60,000 since September; and independents have boomed, growing by nearly 1.3 million since Brown won reelection in 2014 and expanding by more than 300,000 since September.

White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said Monday that the White House is confident in its closing message of the midterm campaign. | Mark Wilson/Getty Images Elections Sarah Sanders holds out hope for GOP House, slams Democrats for ‘obstruction’ agenda

White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders slammed Democrats on Monday for campaigning on “obstruction” in midterm races nationwide, while holding out hope that Republicans might prove pollsters wrong by salvaging a majority in the House of Representatives.

Democrats are widely forecast to pick up House seats in Tuesday’s midterm elections, needing 23 in order to take over as the chamber’s majority party. POLITICO’s final race ratings predict Democrats will claim 25 to 40 additional seats.

Story Continued Below

But Sanders and other Republicans have suggested that the GOP could cling to its majority in the House even as their tone has shifted from confidence to hopefulness. On the eve of Tuesday’s election, the White House press secretary laid into Democrats over what she claimed is the only item on their agenda.

“I still hope that Republicans win the House but if they don't, I think what you've seen the Democrats start talking about is the only message they have, and that’s one of obstruction,” she said in an interview on “Fox and Friends.” “They have no policies, they have no solutions. America’s got some real problems we have to deal with.”

Morning Score newsletter Your guide to the permanent campaign — weekday mornings, in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

President Donald Trump has stepped back in recent days from his past confident predictions that Republicans would hold their House majority, saying that because there are more seats up for grabs, campaigning for GOP House candidates is less efficient than stumping for Republicans running in statewide races.

The campaign schedules of Trump and other officials like Vice President Mike Pence in the waning days of the campaign have underscored that strategy, with stops almost entirely intended to boost Senate and gubernatorial candidates, where the GOP outlook is brighter. The president’s Twitter activity, as well, has skewed more toward statewide races.

On Monday, the president began his day by tweeting another stream of endorsements for Missouri Senate candidate Josh Hawley, Florida gubernatorial candidate Ron DeSantis and Michigan Senate candidate John James following a pair of late night tweets in support of James and California Rep. Dana Rohrabacher.

Trump has already begun to boast that his campaigning has saved the Senate, generally predicted to remain under Republican control, a shift from his past promises that there would be a so-called red wave of GOP enthusiasm in this year’s midterms.

Top Republicans in the House have reportedly implored the president to dial down his bombastic tone, especially on the topic of immigration, and to focus more on the strong state of the economy in an effort to cater to Republican voters in suburban districts.

But Sanders said Monday that the White House is confident in its closing message of the campaign.

“Nobody has worked harder, particularly when their name is not on the ballot, as President Trump has,” she said. “But he is not just doing it at these rallies, but he’s been doing it every single day by impacting good policy and making our country better. You can see that every single thing he has done, whether it’s growing the economy, which he’s put such an emphasis on, whether it’s securing the border, you’re going to see him talk about those things tonight.”

Iranian president Hassan Rouhani said on Monday “we will proudly break the sanctions” that went into effect as a result of President Donald Trump’s decision to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal earlier this year. | STR/AFP/Getty Images Foreign Policy Iranian president vows he will defy new U.S. sanctions

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani pledged Monday that his country would not buckle under the weight of newly re-imposed U.S. sanctions, calling the penalties on its oil and banking sectors “unfair” and “against the law, U.N. resolutions and international accords.”

In a nationally televised address, Rouhani said that “we will proudly break the sanctions” that went into effect at midnight as a result of President Donald Trump’s decision to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal earlier this year.

Story Continued Below

In Washington, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin shared more details about the sanctions, which they described as the strongest and most comprehensive ever imposed by the United States on Iran.

The latest round targets more than 700 individuals, entities, aircraft and vessels — above and beyond sanctions in place before the nuclear deal was struck in 2015. The Trump administration says its goal is to financially starve the Iranian government so that it fundamentally changes its behavior, including ending its support for terrorism.

However, eight “jurisdictions” were given waivers that allow them, for now, to keep importing oil from Iran: China, India, Italy, Greece, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Turkey. Pompeo noted that the U.S. will keep negotiating with these governments to eventually bring their Iranian oil imports down to zero.

The most reliable politics newsletter. Sign up for POLITICO Playbook and get the latest news, every morning — in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Some of the places in question have relied heavily on oil from Iran, and analysts said the exemptions granted them would help keep oil markets stable as they wound down their purchases over time.

Three non-proliferation projects in Iran will also be allowed to continue under exemptions to the sanctions, Pompeo said. He did not give many details but said the exemptions would be “very narrow“ and “time-limited.”

The secretary of state said the United States remains interested in reaching a new agreement with Iran that covers its nuclear activities and other points of dispute. But Iran must “abandon its revolutionary course,” he said.

The U.S. sanctions are particularly harsh because they not only can be levied on Iranian businesses but also on entities outside Iran that do business in the Middle Eastern country. Although some European governments, including Britain, France and Germany, are seeking to find alternatives so that they can keep trade going with Iran, many international firms have nonetheless already pulled out of Iran to avoid hefty U.S. fines.

“We will be strictly enforcing our sanctions,” Mnuchin warned.

Trump teased the sanctions last week on Twitter with a photo-shopped reference to the TV show “Game of Thrones,” writing that "sanctions are coming." Asked whether using such a meme was appropriate, Pompeo pointed to reports that Qassem Soleimani, a feared Iranian military leader, had used his own version of a “Game of Thrones” meme to respond to Trump, promising to “stand against” him.

“This is a man who has American blood on his hands,“ Pompeo said.

Over the weekend, Pompeo promised that the re-imposition of the sanctions will have the intended effect of altering Tehran’s behavior.

“I’m very confident that the sanctions that will be reimposed this Monday, not only the crude oil sanctions but the financial sanctions being put in place by the Treasury Department of over 600 designations of individuals and companies in Iran, will have the intended effect: to alter the Iranian regime’s behavior,” Pompeo said on “Fox News Sunday.” “That’s our expectation. It’s the reason for President Trump’s policy.”

A defiant Rouhani disputed that on Monday, arguing that the waivers already show that the White House’s threats are toothless.

“The Islamic Republic can sell its oil, and even if these eight countries weren’t exempted, we would have still sold our oil,” Rouhani said. “Isn’t that success?”

HOW REPUBLICANS CAN KEEP THE HOUSE -- Ryan phones Trump -- WOMAN POISED TO JOIN SENATE GOP LEADERSHIP -- Obamacare repeal still on the table?

By Nolan D. McCaskill ( nmccaskill@politico.com or @NolanDMcCaskill )

PATH TO THE MAJORITY -- House Republicans would need to win nearly all of the 22 races POLITICO rates as toss-ups to keep their majority, according to a new analysis. POLITICO’s final race ratings show 216 seats either solidly, likely or leaning Democratic. “That’s a significantly stronger position than Republicans, who have 197 seats leaning or solidly in their camp, but still just shy of the 218 needed to control the House next year,” Steven Shepard reports. “Republicans would need to win at least 21 of the 22 toss-ups -- races that are currently considered too close to call -- to get to 218 seats.”

Story Continued Below

Democrats needs to pick up 23 seats to win the majority. The ratings indicate that Democrats are likely to pick up between 25 and 40 seats. “A Democratic-controlled House ... would represent a rebuke to Trump, even with a booming economy, and grind much of his legislative agenda to a halt until the 2020 election,” he adds. “But the president will likely have something about which to crow on Tuesday night: His party is likely to keep control of the Senate and could expand its narrow majority, even as it loses significant ground in the House.” More: https://politi.co/2PbNeAP

Related: “Trump says he’s focused on Senate,” by The Associated Press’ Zeke Miller and Jill Colvin: http://bit.ly/2JFOTIS

HOUSE GOP IN PANIC MODE -- House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) implored the president in a phone call Sunday to talk about the economy in the final hours of the campaign cycle. Trump -- who will hold his final midterm campaign rallies today in Cleveland; Fort Wayne, Indiana; and Cape Girardeau, Missouri -- bragged that his rhetoric on immigration has fired up the base. “Republicans focused on the chamber are profoundly worried that Trump’s obsession with all things immigration will exacerbate their losses,” Rachael, Carla Marinucci and Elana report. “Many of these same Republicans welcomed Trump’s initial talk about the migrant caravan and border security two weeks ago, hoping it would gin up the GOP base in some at-risk, Republican-held districts.”

“But they now fear Trump went overboard -- and that it could cost them dearly in key suburban districts, from Illinois to Texas,” they write. Privately, some House Republicans say the president abandoned them to focus on the Senate. While Trump’s approach likely helps Senate Republicans expand their majority in rural, red states, it hurts House Republicans’ efforts to save their majority in the suburbs. “Trump has hijacked the election,” one senior House Republican aide said. “This is not what we expected the final weeks of the election to focus on.” More: https://politi.co/2Dmt54U

Related read: “‘Full Trumpism’: The president’s apocalyptic attacks reach a new level of falsity,” from The Washington Post’s Philip Rucker: https://wapo.st/2zr5JGV

PELOSI PROFILE -- What is it like to be House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.)? “Republicans are running ads against you again, morphing your face into a monster mask of a big-spending, amnesty-loving San Francisco liberal,” The New York Times’ Kate Zernike writes. “Democratic candidates are running from your leadership, declaring it time for a new generation in Washington even as they welcome endorsements from Joe Biden, who’s been around nearly two decades longer.” You’re the most powerful woman in American politics yet are depicted in one ad by a woman walking in a cheap version of stilettos. “Has anyone ever attempted to tar a candidate with Chuck Schumer’s reading glasses or Mitch McConnell’s wingtips?” Zernike asks.

Women, Pelosi says, can’t run from fights. “Know your power, know your why, know your what, know your how, connect with your voters and people who are supportive, those you wish to convince,” Pelosi tells women. “But don’t let them think you are running away.” Pelosi is still fighting to become speaker again, despite being targeted by Republicans and distanced from some Democrats. She not only knows her power but declares it, telling audiences she’s a “dazzling fundraiser” and “master legislator.” She understands why some Democrats running in Republican districts oppose her but doesn’t dwell on those who are unlikely to win. “My time is big money,” she says. More: https://nyti.ms/2RzAjp9

WOMEN EYE SENATE LEADERSHIP POST -- Mitch McConnell’s (R-Ky.) leadership team could soon include a woman for the first time since 2010. Sens. Deb Fischer (R-Neb.) and Joni Ernst (R-Iowa) are running for the No. 5 post, Senate GOP Conference vice chair. “The race is expected to be close, putting the mostly male conference in an awkward position of choosing between two up-and-coming female members,” Burgess reports. “Some Republican senators are trying to pick sides delicately, while others will simply vote on the secret ballot and never disclose which senator they favored.” Sen. Richard Shelby (R-Ala.), however, will back Fischer because she asked him to first.

The race has been ongoing since this summer but will ramp up after Tuesday’s elections. Senators say neither candidate has a clear edge, but both will try to lock up the 26 or so votes they need in the Nov. 14 leadership elections. “Ernst is expected to face a tough reelection campaign in 2020, while Fischer is expected to win reelection handily on Tuesday,” Burgess notes. Ernst also “breaks with President Donald Trump’s rhetoric on occasion. Fischer is closer with more senior senators, and her messaging is more consistently in line with Trump’s and GOP leaders.” More: https://politi.co/2PFKECN

BLOOMBERG’S $5M BOOST -- Former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg has launched a $5 million national ad campaign for Democrats -- and himself. The two-minute spot aired last night during CBS’ “60 Minutes” and will air tonight during evening news programs on broadcast networks and on CNN and MSNBC. “While formally a pitch for Democrats -- to whom Bloomberg has given more than $110 million this election cycle -- the ad is also revealing of the kind of presentation he could bring to the 2020 campaign trail,” The Washington Post’s Robert Costa writes. “The country is deeply divided,” Bloomberg said in a statement. “The president and Republicans are fueling that division, and that holds us back as a nation. I’m unwilling to sit by and accept it.” More: https://wapo.st/2D1poAE

SINEMA CLOSES IN ON AZ SENATE SEAT -- Rep. Kyrsten Sinema (D-Ariz.) quipped at a campaign event that “they’re coming for us” after a poster behind her noisily fell to the ground as she was speaking. “Sinema’s opponent, GOP Rep. Martha McSally, has tarred her as a liberal in centrist’s clothing, running ads contrasting the Republican’s Air Force service with the Democrat’s past as an antiwar activist clad in a pink tutu,” Elana writes. “But the hits, like Sinema’s poster, don’t seem to be sticking.” Polls show Sinema either tied with McSally or narrowly leading in a red state that has elected famously independent-minded Republicans such as Jeff Flake and the late John McCain.

“Arizona’s strong early vote totals have Sinema backers hopeful that she will be the first Democrat elected statewide since former Gov. Janet Napolitano (D-Ariz.) was reelected to a second term in 2006,” Elana adds. “McSally betrayed a hint of frustration with what she called a disingenuous makeover by her opponent.” McSally said Sinema has been on TV since April, pouring tens of millions of dollars in ads portraying herself as right of center without mentioning she’s a Democrat. “To people who are out there just living their lives ... you can fool a lot of people with tens of millions of dollars pretending you’re something that you’re not,” McSally said. More: https://politi.co/2qs7rnj

Related: “McSally flames ‘activist’ Sinema at Arizona GOP cookout,” per Elana: https://politi.co/2PEDYVl ; and “‘Tale of the tape’: Senate battlegrounds will show if Democrats have found the way to win in Trump states,” via The Washington Post’s Sean Sullivan: https://wapo.st/2RAwIHr

DID BETO BLOW IT? -- Rep. Beto O’Rourke (D-Texas) highlighted bipartisanship in a unique way, hitting the road with Rep. Will Hurd (R-Texas) for a 24-hour, 1,600-mile trip from San Antonio, Texas, to Washington, D.C., in March 2017. Two weeks later, he launched his Senate campaign, which rejected corporate money, avoided negative attacks and didn’t employ any pollsters or consultants. “By offering a cause rather than a candidacy, O’Rourke convinced America that a Texas Democrat could win statewide for the first time since 1994,” Tim Alberta writes.

“A staggering $70 million flooded into his campaign,” he continues. “Celebrities came calling on a first-name basis. LeBron James made the black-and-white ‘Beto’ signage famous. National reporters took turns deifying the skateboarding, punk-rocking congressman. And all the while, O’Rourke was flatlining.” O’Rourke hasn’t broken 47 percent in any public or private poll this cycle. Many Texas Republicans don’t like Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas). Some even want Cruz to lose. “And all of them are baffled by the disconnect between the superior branding of O’Rourke’s candidacy and what they see as the tactical malpractice of his campaign,” Alberta adds. O’Rourke did little to win over the Republicans and independents who are open to opposing Cruz. More: https://politi.co/2D3WRKQ

THE FATE OF OBAMACARE -- If Republicans maintain control of the House and Senate, they will have to determine whether to mount another effort to repeal Obamacare. “The GOP believes it can’t just walk away from an eight-year pledge to repeal the law, a promise the party’s base still wants Republicans to keep despite Obamacare’s relative new popularity,” Adam Cancryn writes. “If an election-night shocker keeps Republicans in power -- rebuking the conventional wisdom that voters will punish them for their Obamacare attacks -- they might be emboldened to mount another repeal push without risking reprisals at the polls next time around.”

Republicans, however, have no viable replacement plan. And even with a House majority, they wouldn’t have the numbers. “Republicans’ advantage in the chamber would shrink to just two or three votes under even the rosiest midterm projections, leaving virtually no room for error in rounding up votes for a repeal package guaranteed to be divisive,” he adds. “A Republican-controlled Congress, with an eye toward reelecting President Donald Trump in 2020, could pursue party-unifying issues instead, like another round of tax cuts Trump dangled before the midterms. But take up Obamacare repeal again and the GOP would invite another brutal, months-long health care war facing long odds and littered with stumbling blocks.” More: https://politi.co/2Peo3xN

TRANSITIONS -- Mathew Weidinger will be a resident fellow in the economic policy department at the American Enterprise Institute. He most recently was deputy staff director for the House Ways and Means Committee.

Aniela Butler is now a professional staff member on the Senate Budget Committee, focusing on energy and natural resources. She was previously a legislative assistant for Sen. Mike Enzi (R-Wyo.).

OBAMA's sharp turn to Chicago — WBEZ unravels the Quincy debacle — COUNTDOWN with the campaigns

Happy Election Eve, Illinois! We’ve got a rundown of the campaigns before tomorrow’s big day.

THE BUZZ

A hoarse but energized Barack Obama got sentimental Sunday while in Chicago to campaign for J.B. Pritzker, Kwame Raoul and other Illinois Dems. It was 10 years ago to the day he won the presidency. “When the cynics said we couldn’t, we said, ‘Yes, we can.’ And that night we said that, yes, we did,” he told the crowd 5,000-plus at the UIC Pavilion. “Goodness and decency is still out there. Kindness is still out there. Generosity is still out there. Hope is still out there. We just have to stand up and speak for it.”

Story Continued Below

That was it for sentimentality. Obama’s 45-minute speech hammered at Republicans for, among other things, “blatantly, repeatedly, baldly, shamelessly lying.” Obama took issue with the current administration’s stances on immigration, tax cuts for the wealthy and, especially, the Affordable Care Act.

Isn’t it funny, he said in a folksy, relaxed way, that Republican candidates are clamoring to support insurance coverage for pre-existing medical conditions even though they voted against that while in Congress. “That’s a lot of gall. That’s a lot of nerve. That’s a lot of chutzpah,” Obama said. He used the discussion of ACA to give a hat tip to Lauren Underwood, the nurse running to unseat Republican incumbent Randy Hultgren in the exurban 14th District. Underwood worked for the Obama administration and its efforts to write Obamacare, as the ACA is called.

Democats hung on Obama’s words and the rhythm and color that define how he speaks. But this Obama also took a sharp turn to attack Republicans. It was unlike the speech he gave 10 years ago.

On Sunday night, Obama criticized the White House for trying to distract voters with the trumped-up drama about the immigrant caravan. “Don’t be hoodwinked, don’t be bamboozled. Do not fall for the okey-doke,” Obama said of the GOP rhetoric. And he poked fun, saying if Republicans “really cared” about Hillary Clinton’s emails, they would also care about the Chinese listening to the president’s cell phone. It was one of the many lines that drew big applause.

New voice or not, it was music to the ears of the 5,000-plus supporters, many of whom waited in line in the rain to get in to hear him speak. They cheered and whooped and a few booed at mention of the Trump administration, prompting Obama to say repeatedly, “Don’t boo. Vote.“

Obama wrapped up by locking hands with Pritzker and lieutenant governor candidate Juliana Stratton. And he gave hugs to congressional candidates Underwood and Sean Casten, state Comptroller Susana Mendoza and Treasurer Mike Frerichs. When Obama approached Kwame Raoul for a similar embrace, the state senator in a tough battle for attorney general gave the former president a giant bear hug. Raoul holds the seat once held by Obama. Sentimental indeed. (More on who attended, below.)

MORE BUZZ

Thousands of documents released to WBEZ on Friday—just four days before the election—reveal the governor’s office exacerbated the mishandling of the Legionnaires’ disease crisis by not being more forthright with the public and media. The governor’s office “should have followed our advice” and just released the documents “with no redactions. Now we have another mess created by them to deal with,” wrote an aide in the state public health office. THe emails “flesh out the image of a governor's office repeatedly overruling its own top experts in order to control and constrict what information was made public about successive deadly Legionnaires' outbreaks,” report Dave McKinney and Tony Arnold. Story here

CAMPAIGNS

— Undaunted by polls that show him down, Gov. Bruce Rauner spent the rainy Sunday on a campaign bus, traveling to cafes and bars in Decatur, Gibson City, Morris and St. Charles. Rauner, too, led a rally for Republicans in one Cook County stop in Orland Park. At Honest Abe’s Tap & Grill in Morris, the governor spoke of an uphill battle back to a second term, while warning it would be “a nightmare” for the state to elect Democrat J.B. Pritzker. “People are counting us out now. They’re saying, ‘Oh the polls are showing this or that,'” Rauner said. “You know what? The polls are baloney. These polls don’t mean anything. The only poll that matters is on Election Day.” Sun-Times’ Tina Sfondeles reports. Story here

— Checks on government. J.B. Pritzker and Barack Obama talked Sunday about electing Democrats to keep a check on government. So POLITICO asked Pritzker how that differs from Republican Erika Harold saying she’s the best candidate to keep a check on government in Illinois. She’s a Republican after all. Isn’t it the same thing? Pritzker says “it’s not about Democrat or Republican.” The attorney general job is ‘independent‘ of what goes on in the governor’s office, Pritzker said. If donations are any indication about this race—it’s a must watch on Tuesday. House Speaker Mike Madigan, the Dem Party chairman, just donated $1 million to Raoul’s campaign.

— In IL-6, the race between six-term Republican Rep. Roskam and Democrat Sean Casten is important in the national battle for the House majority, but also because it could define how a collar county has transformed from a Republican bastion to an increasingly Democratic enclave. And the gerrymandering hasn’t even yet begun. The Washington Post has a good story that looks at how Roskam finds himself on the thinnest of political ice, Story here . And NBC/5’s Mary Ann Ahern looks at how contentious the race has become--the campaigns have even gone to court. Story here

— In IL-12, it’s the “L” word. Republican Rep. Mike Bost called Democrat Brendan Kelly “a wolf in sheep’s clothing” for casting himself as a moderate Dem instead of an “extreme liberal.” Like other Republicans who have leaned on Nancy Pelosi and Mike Madigan to fuel their rhetoric, Bost compared Kelly to Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, whom he describes as “the face of the ‘resistance.’” On Sunday, Kelly’s campaign announced he’s received the endorsement of 20 mayors across southern Illinois.

— In IL-13, Betsy Dirksen Londrigan joined state Reps. Andy Manar (48) and Carol Ammons (103) at several church services Sunday for “Souls to the Polls,” a get out the vote effort. Londrigan faces Republican Rep. Rodney Davis. Remember this was the race that saw Davis make headlines when his field director was arrested last summer for picking a fight at a Londrigan event. POLITICO’s Race Ratings has the contest leaning Republican.

— In IL-14, the latest New York Times live poll has Lauren Underwood up 49 percent to Randy Hultgren’s 43 percent. With 8 percent undecided, this race could go either way. Poll here TV watchers cn see Underwood is outspending Hultgren in ads. Her face is everywhere. And FEC filings through mid-October show Underwood having raised $3.7 million to Hultgren’s $2.1 million. Underwood, who stood on stage with Barack Obama at a rally Sunday, will be on an Airstream tour today starting in Gurnee at 8:45 a.m., then visiting Lake Villa GOTV volunteers in Fox Lake at 9:30 a.m., Woodstock campaign volunteers at noon, Sun City residents in Huntley at 2 p.m., and St. Charles campaign volunteers at 5:15 p.m. Details here Hultgren spent Saturday with House Speaker Paul Ryan, who hit Illinois to stump for candidates.

This is the race that pits Republican and avowed Nazi Art Jones and veteran Democrat Rep. Dan Lipinski. While Lipinski hasn’t said much about Jones’ history, write-in Justin Hanson has. He’s putting yard signs up next to Jones’ and identifying the GOP candidate as a Nazi. Kenneth Yerkes also is a write-in candidate. Story here

They depart Rockford early this morning for a string of rallies: Quad Cities airport in Moline at 8 a.m., Laborers local 459 in Belleville at 10:30 a.m., IUOE Local 318 in Marion at 12:30 p.m., airport public safety building in Springfield at 2:45 p.m., Laborers Local 165 in Peoria at 5 p.m. Along with Pritzker will be lieutenant governor candidate Juliana Stratton, U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin, Treasurer Mike Frerichs and AG nominee Kwame Raoul.
